questions.text: What is the origin of the vaginal epithelium?
questions.solution:
The cranial one third as well as caudal two third ( ie entire vaginal epithelium ) of vaginal epithelium is derived from endoderm of urogenital sinus.

questions.text: What part of the following does not belong to the ethmoid bone?

Inferior turbinate is not the part of ethmoid bone.

The other three options are however a part of the ethmoid bone.

questions.text: Which part of the fallopian tube acts as a physiological sphincter?

Intramural part: narrowest part serving as anatomical sphincter, Isthmus: 2nd narrowest part of fallopian tube serving as physiological spincter.

questions.text: What is the most vital source of blood for the stomach?
questions.solution:
Most important blood supply to the stomach is the left gastric artery.

The left gastric artery is the branch of the celiac axis andis the largest artery supplying the stomach.

Blood Supply of Stomach:

 
  • Left gastric artery:Branch of celiac trunk (Largest) 
  • Right gastric artery: Branch of hepatic artery
  • Right gastroepiploic artery: Branch of gastroduodenal artery 
  • Left gastroepiploic artery: Branch of splenic artery
  • Short gastric arteries: Branch of splenic artery

questions.text: What does the phrase "dynamic stabiliser of the shoulder joint" refer to?
questions.solution:
'Dynamic stabilizer of shoulder joint’ is used for rotator cuff or musculotendinous cuff.

The tendons of the subscapularis, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and teres minor muscles that are united to the underlying capsule of the shoulder joint are referred to as the rotator cuff. The cuff is crucial in maintaining the stability of the shoulder joint.

Ciliary muscles develop from the Neural crest.

questions.text: Which muscle is physically in the back but functionally in the thorax?
questions.solution:
Levator costae is anatomically a back muscle but functionally related to thorax, because it helps to elevate the ribs during inspiration, it does not perform functions of typical back muscles.

Medulla is not supplied by the Superior Cerebellar artery.

questions.text: What nerves innervate the external anal sphincter?
questions.solution:
External anal sphincter is innervated by inferior rectal branch of pudendal nerve (anterior divisions of S2, S3, S4 sacral spinal nerves) mainly and by perineal branch of S4.

Pudendal nerve is the main sensory motor nerve of the perineum and sensory nerve of the genitalia.




Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e42,1201

questions.text: Which nerve root supplies the thumb and index finger dermatomes ?
questions.solution:
The thumb and index finger dermatomes are supplied by the C6 and C7 nerve roots , respectively. The dermatomes are the areas of skin innervated by the various spinal nerve roots. The C6 nerve root innervates the thumb, while the C7 nerve root innervates the index finger. The C5, C6, C7, and C8 nerve roots supply the muscles of the hand and wrist, and they are responsible for sensation in the corresponding dermatomes.




 

Reference:Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics, 13th edition Page no 1445

questions.text:
A patient who had trouble extending his fingers upon awakening is now able to form a grip and handle a pen. The dorsiflexion was typical. Examination of the senses and muscles was normal.
Which is the most frequently affected nerve?
questions.solution:
Nerve most commonly involved is Posterior interosseous nerve.

The following are symptoms of posterior interosseous nerve palsy: 

 
  • Lesion may make it challenging to extend your fingers. 
  • Sensations (including the ability to construct a grip and hold a pen) and the elbow, wrist, and interphalangeal joint extension are unaffected. The dorsiflexor was normal. The sensory and motor examinations are normal. 
  • Metacarpophalangeal joint extension lost


Reference- Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma 10th Edition Page no 295

questions.text: Which intercostal area (other than the rib) does not have a regular vein, artery, and nerve (VAN) arrangement?
questions.solution:
Regular vein, artery and nerve ('VAN') arrangement is not present in the first intercostal space.

The first intercostal vessels and nerve pass along the lower surface between intercostal intimi and costal pleura with arrangements of nerve, artery and vein from above downwards.



Reference-:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 943-945 and 979

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't have a mesorectal fascia covering?
questions.solution:
Inferior rectal vein is not enclosed in mesorectal fascia.

Contents of Mesorectal fascia:

questions.text: Where does the autonomous distribution of paternal and maternal chromosomes take place in spermatogenesis?
questions.solution:
In spermatogenesis, independent assortment of paternal and maternal chromosomes occurs during meiosis I, in which primary spermatocyte (2n) is converted into two secondary spermatocytes (n).

Meiosis I separates pairs of homologous chromosomes, reduces the cell from diploid to haploid, hence is also called as reductional division.


Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 16,17

questions.text: What does the given EEG suggest?
questions.solution:
Given EEG is suggestive of polyspike and wave, seen in myoclonic epilepsy.

Myoclonic Seizures:

Myoclonic seizures are short-lived, shock-like muscular contractions, and even when they are widespread, they don't cause any discernible impairments in consciousness. 

Myoclonic seizures mostly affect the shoulders, upper extremities, and face and can happen as separate episodes or in clusters, in which case they are typically not rhythmic.

questions.text: Where does sympathetic stimulation cause the blood flow to decrease?
questions.solution:
Sympathetic stimulation decreases blood flow in skin. Sympathetic Stimulation: Stimulation of sympathetic fibers causes vasoconstriction but it is not important, as the vasocontricor system is not Sympathetic.stimulation increases myocardial blood flow through an increased metabolic demand and a predominance of beta-receptor activation. Sympathetic system doesn't change the cerebral and renal blood flow as they are managed by auto-regulation.

choices.text: Acetylcholine is released at the nerve terminal
Calcium is pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum during relaxation
Calcium is released from sarcoplasmic reticulum during contraction
Calcium binds to tropomyosin to initiate muscle contraction

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about excitation-contraction coupling?
questions.solution:
Calcium binds to Troponin C, not to the tropomyosin, to initiate muscle contraction. This binding exposes the Actin binding sites present on the myosin band which were earlier guarded by the tropomyosin helix. E-C coupling proceeds as follows: The membrane potential of a skeletal muscle cell is depolarised by an action potential (e.g. from synaptic activation from an alpha motor neuron) This depolarisation activates voltage-gated DHPRS This activates RyR type 1 via physical linkage As the RyRs open, calcium is released from the SR into the local junctional space, which then diffuses into the bulk cytoplasm to cause a calcium transient. . The calcium released into the cytosol binds to Troponin C by the actin filaments, to allow cross-bridge cycling, producing force and, in some situations, motion. The sarco/endoplasmic reticulum calcium-ATPase (SERCA) actively pumps calcium back into the SR. As calcium declines back to resting levels, the force declines and relaxation occurs.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 104

questions.text: What is the basis for transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation?
questions.solution:
Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) is based on gate-controlled theory of pain.

The working of the spinal pain suppression mechanism is explained by the gate control hypothesis. This theory holds that the dorsal grey horn serves as a gate for the transmission of pain sensation, and that segmental suppression and supraspinal suppression can partially or completely seal this gate.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 169

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Kluver-Bucy syndrome?
questions.solution:
Hyperactivity is not seen in Klüver-Bucy syndrome. Features of the syndrome include: Visual agnosia Increased oral tendency Decreased emotional reaction Hypersexuality, Hypermetamorphosis( increased curosity and tendency to explore the surrounding), Placidity is decreased emotional reaction.

Kluver Bucky syndrome is associated with fro to temporal dementia where decision making, empathy and emotional compromise is present . The patient presents with hyperphagia, hyperorality (no inhibitions, says what comes to mind), hyper sexuality.


Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK544221/

Mean arterial pressure, which is responsible for blood flow to an organ

questions.text: Which is the best indicator for peripheral resistance?
questions.solution:
Peripheral resistance is best indicated by Diastolic blood pressure.

The diastolic component of blood pressure is made up of peripheral resistance, which regulates peripheral blood supply due to the opening of conduction vessels during left ventricular diastole. As a result, an increase in systemic resistance leads to an increase in diastolic blood pressure.




Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538308/

questions.text: Where is the blood-testis barrier located?
questions.solution:
Blood testis barrier is located between sertoli and sertoli cells.

Sertoli cells are connected by tight junctions, the body's strongest intercellular barriers. This configuration forms the blood testes barrier. The blood testes barrier protects developing sperms from immune attack and blood borne noxious agents.

The tight junctions forms the major barriers in our body like the blood brain barrier, the blood testes barrier etc.
Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 411,412

questions.text: What is the most common progesterone metabolite discharged in urine?
questions.solution:
Most common metabolite of progesterone excreted in urine is Pregnanediol.

The principal pathway of the metabolism of progesterone is progesterone -> pregnanedione - pregnanolone >- pregnanediol, this pregnanediol is then excreted in the urine.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 400,401

questions.text: Which among the following is referred to as a suicidal enzyme?
questions.solution:
Cyclooxygenase is a suicidal enzyme.

Suicidal enzyme is one, which undergoes self-destruction in order to terminate its own activity, e.g. Cyclooxygenase.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 224.

questions.text: Which of the following is not responsible for ketosis in a patient with Von Gierke disease?
questions.solution:
Option 4, "Low fat mobilization", is the correct answer because it is not responsible for ketosis in a patient with Von Gierke disease.

In fact, individuals with Von Gierke disease have an increased tendency to accumulate fat in their liver, which can lead to further complications.
Therefore, options 1, 2, and 3 are incorrect because they are all associated with hypoglycemia, which is a primary feature of Von Gierke disease and can lead to ketosis.
Option 4 is the correct answer because low fat mobilization is not a contributing factor to ketosis in individuals with Von Gierke disease.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 174.

questions.text: What determines the exact placement of a genomic loci?
questions.solution:
Exact location of a genetic loci is identified by Fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH).

FISH, which uses fluorescent rather than radioactively labeled probes, is a very sensitive technique for determining the exact location of a genetic loci.

This frequently places the gene on a given band or region of the chromosome.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 165.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about ribozyme?
questions.solution:
Ribozymes are RNA molecules that can catalyze reactions. Ribozymes are important in the formation of peptide bonds (peptidyl transferase activity).

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 54.

questions.text: Which enzyme's activity increases when insulin /glucagon  level are low?
questions.solution:
Insulin suppresses glucose-6-phosphatase gene. Glucose-6-phosphatase activity is increased in low insulin/glucagon level.

In these kind of questions - High I/G ratio means fed state vs Low I/G ratio points towards fasting. Now think what body does then - Here’s a concise table showing which processes occur during the fed and fasting states:
Process Fed State Fasting State
Glycogenesis Active (liver, muscle) Inactive
Glycogenolysis Inactive Active (liver, muscle)
Glycolysis Active Inactive
Gluconeogenesis Inactive Active (liver, kidney)
Lipogenesis Active (liver, adipose) Inactive
Lipolysis Inactive Active (adipose tissue)
Ketogenesis Inactive Active (liver)
Proteolysis Inactive Active (muscle)

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 188.

choices.text: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency causes decreased synthesis of NADPH

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding NADPH is false?
questions.solution:
NADPH does not produce ATP in RBCs as RBC lacks mitochondria. 

NADPH is required for:

 
  • As a co-enzyme, it performs reductive biosynthesis of all lipids, including fatty acid synthesis, cholesterol synthesis, and bile acid synthesis. 
  • Regenerating depleted glutathione in RBCs and stabilising or protecting the membrane from oxidative stress.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 193.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is not a component of the fatty acid synthase complex?
questions.solution:
Acetyl Co-1 carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis and is an enzyme, which is not a component of fatty acid synthase complex.

Mnemonic: ATC-KER (A Train Can Keep Elongating Reactions)

  1. A: Acetyl Transferase (AT)
    • Transfers acetyl group to the enzyme.
  2. T: Malonyl Transferase (MT)
    • Transfers malonyl group to the enzyme.
  3. C: Condensing Enzyme (CE)
    • Combines acetyl and malonyl groups, releasing CO.
  4. K: β-Ketoacyl Reductase (KR)
    • Reduces the β-keto group using NADPH.
  5. E: Enoyl Reductase (ER
    • Reduces the double bond using NADPH.
  6. R: Thioesterase (TE)
    • Releases the finished fatty acid (palmitate) from the complex.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 227.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of megaloblastic anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Increased reticulocyte count
 
  • Megaloblastic anemia refers to deficiency in B12 and Folate leading to anemia.
  • Both B12 and folate are crucial for generation of nuclear material for a new cell. their deficiency leads to inability of the cells to decide and mature, the cells hence remain nucleated and large in size, increased destruction of cells causes jaundice and splenomegaly.
  • Reticulocyte count remains low.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 651.

questions.text: What causes platelet adherence to collagen?
questions.solution:
Platelet adhesion to collagen occurs via von-Willebrand factor

Certain proteins are presented on the platelet’s external surface that subsequently regulate collagen-induced platelet adhesion, including glycoprotein (GP)-IV, GP-VI, and the integrin-alpha 2, and beta1.

The GPIb-IX-V complex binds to the exposed von-Willebrand factor, causing platelets to adhere.


Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 120

questions.text: A light microscope can be used to see chromosomes with a resolution of ____?
questions.solution:
Chromosomes are visualized through a light microscope with resolution of 5 mb.

This analysis is called Karyotype analysis.

It helps to detect both numerical and structural chromosomal aberrations.

Overall resolution in this procedure is 5 Mega bases (mb).

questions.text: What factors influence the tensile strength of a 30-year-old woman's wound after a laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
questions.solution:
#controversial
Correct Answer is Option 3 - Extensive crosslink of tropocollagen (Controversial question as both option 1 and 3 contribute to tensile strength of wound) 
 
  • The tensile strength of a wound depends on factors such as collagen synthesis and organization and the type of collagen. 
  • Extensive crosslinking of tropocollagen is the main factor for achieving tensile strength and hence is a better answer amongst other options.
Option 1 Replacement of type 3 collagen is associated with wound healing and increases the tensile strength also. 
Option 2 and 4 
Macrophage activity/invasion and granulation tissue formation are important processes in wound healing but are not specifically related to the tensile strength of the wound.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 442.

questions.text: In a 70 years old man who was working in asbestos factory for 10-15 years. On routine X-ray, a mass was seen in right apical region of the lung. Biopsy was taken from the mass. Which of the following is seen on electron microscopic examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Numerous long slender microvilli
 
  • Most likely diagnosis on the basis of description is malignant mesothelioma.
  • Numerous long, slender microvilli will be seen on electron microscopy in malignant mesothelioma.
  • Contrast this with short stubby microvilli seen in Adeno carcinoma. Mesotheliomas are the most specific neoplasms associated with asbestosis. They can develop 1-2 years after exposure, but the incidence is highest 20-35 years after exposure.
  • Displays a strong male preference (3:1) The presence of long microvilli and abundant tonofilaments on electron microscopy, but absent microvillous rootlets and lamellar bodies, favors the diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 726.

questions.text: Which of the following causes apoptosis in a cell?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Glucocorticoids

Glucocorticoids induce apoptosis in a cell.

* [Extra Edge]: Inducers of apoptosis

  • Growth factor withdrawal
  • Detachment from matrix 
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Cytotoxic drugs
  • Immune cytolysis

Glucocorticoid-induced apoptosis affects the skeletal system, muscular system, circulatory system, nervous system, endocrine system, endocrine system and immune system.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 108.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presented with painless supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. A biopsy revealed binucleated acidophilic owl eyed cells with floating lymphocytes in empty space that were CD15 and CD30 positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for the described case is 2. Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin lymphoma.

The presence of binucleated Reed-Sternberg cells (often described as "owl-eyed" cells), along with the floating lymphocytes in an empty space, and the positivity for CD15 and CD30 are characteristic features of Hodgkin lymphoma.
Nodular sclerosis is the most common subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma and is typically associated with the clinical presentation of painless lymphadenopathy, particularly in the supraclavicular region.

RS cells are of different types in different types of classical Hodgkins Lymphoma - 
  1. Mixed cellularity - Mononuclear RS cell
  2. Nodular sclerosis - Lacunar cell
  3. Lymphocyte rich - Classical RS cell
  4. Lymphocyte depleted - Pleomorphic/Reticular cell
In non classical Hodgkins - Lymphocyte predominant NHL - Popcorn or LH cells are seen.

Lymphocyte rich variant is the best answer but it's not in the option. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 612.

questions.text: What is the objective of a real-time polymerase chain reaction?
questions.solution:
Real time polymerase chain reaction is done for monitoring amplification of target nucleic acid.

A quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR), also known as real-time polymerase chain reaction, is a molecular biology laboratory technique that uses the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to amplify and simultaneously quantify the targeted DNA molecule.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: Which is the correct match between drug and mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Brimonidine decreases aqueous production

Brimonidine lowers IOP by reducing aqueous production and by increasing uveoscleral flow. Brimonidine is alpha-2 agonist therefore it causes vasoconstriction and inhibits aqueous humor production.

Option B- Latanoprost is a PGF2 alpha analogue which acts by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
Option C- Pilocarpine is a cholinergic drug which acts by increasing trabecular outflow.
Option D- Betaxolol is a beta 1 antagonist which acts by decreasing aqueous production.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 168.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of Rho kinase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fasudil 

  • Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitors, such as fasudil, ripasudil, and netarsudil, target the ROCK pathway, influencing smooth muscle contraction, fibrosis, and cellular motility. They are primarily used in treating glaucoma (reducing intraocular pressure) and cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid hemorrhage. They also show potential for pulmonary hypertension, fibrosis, cancer, and neurological recovery. Side effects include conjunctival hyperemia and hypotension.
  • Fasudil is an inhibitor of smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary vasospasm in experimental animals. In clinical trials in patients with CAD, it has improved performance in stress tests. It is investigational in angina.
  • Fasudil appears to reduce pulmonary artery pressure in PAH. Surgical treatment for advanced disease includes creation of a right atrial to left atrial shunt and lung transplantation.


Option 2 Ranolazine is a novel antianginal drug primarily acts by inhibiting a late Na+ current (late INa) in the myocardium which indirectly facilitates Ca2+ entry through Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.
Option 3 Amiloride block ENaCs in the luminal membrane of principal cells in late distal tubules and collecting ducts by binding to a site in the channel pore.
Option 4 Nicorandil is a dual mechanism antianginal drug activates ATP sensitive K+ channels (KATP) in smooth muscle membrane thereby hyperpolarizing and relaxing it.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 313.

choices.text: It causes acute inhibition of iodotyrosine and iodothyronine synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the uses of iodine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Its use is contraindicated in hyperthyroidism

Iodine is not contraindicated in hyperthyroidism.

Iodine is used to treat hyperthyroidism in the following ways: 

  • In the perioperative period in preparation for thyroidectomy. 
  • In conjunction with other antithyroid drugs and propranolol in the treatment of thyrotoxicosis. 
* Excess iodine prevents release of T3 and T4 this is known as Wolf-Chaikoff effect.

Thyroid hormone release is inhibited: One important clinical effect of high iodine is the inhibition of thyroid hormone release, which is rapid and effective in severe thyrotoxicosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: How long does flumazenil take to start working?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) within seconds
 
  • Flumazenil typically starts its action within 60- 90 seconds of IV administration.
  • Duration of action of flumazenil is 40 minutes. It is a BZD analogue, with little intrinsic activity, used in overdose of BZD.
  • On IV injection, action of flumazenil starts in seconds and lasts for 1-2 hours; elimination t-half is 1 hour, due to rapid metabolism.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 435.

questions.text: What medication has both alpha and beta agonist properties?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Epinephrine

Epinephrine or adrenaline has both alpha and beta receptor action, with a weak effect on the gamma receptor.

Option 1 Fenoldopam is not an inducer of either alpha, beta, or gamma receptors, but rather is a selective agonist on dopamine-1 receptors.
Option 2 Dopamine is a dopaminergic (D1 and D2) as well as weaker adrenergic β1 (but not β2) + very weak α receptor agonist.
Option 4 Phenylephrine is a selective alpha agonist with no effect on beta receptors




Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 142.

questions.text: Which of the following medicines can be immediately stopped without causing withdrawal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Fluoxetine
 
  • Fluoxetine can be stopped abruptly without any withdrawal symptoms due to its long half life [t1/2= 2 days].
  • It is the longest acting SSRI.
  • Side-effects of the fluoxetine discontinuation are unusual and very mild, especially compared to paroxetine, venlafaxine and fluvoxamine, owing to the relatively long pharmacological half-life of fluoxetine.
  • Other short acting SSRIs, including Escitalopram, Fluvoxamine, and Sertraline, have shorter half-lives and are more likely to cause withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly. This is known as Discontinuation syndrome.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 488, 489.

questions.text: What is the name given to the body's ability to eliminate the drug from the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Clearance

The clearance of the drug is the theoretical volume of plasma from which the drug is completely removed in unit time. 

It can be calculated as:

Clearance = Rate of elimination/Concentration



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 38.

choices.text: Has been known to cause Steven-Johnson's syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements about carbamazepine is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Has been known to cause Steven-Johnson's syndrome 

  • Carbamazepine has been known to cause Steven-Johnson's syndrome.
  • Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to medication that starts with flu-like symptoms, followed by a painful rash that spreads and blisters. Then the top layer of affected skin dies, sheds and begins to heal after several days.
  • Acute intoxication with carbamazepine can result in stupor or coma, hyperirritability, convulsions, and respiratory depression.
  • During Long term therapy, the more frequent untoward effects of the drug include drowsiness, vertigo, ataxia, diplopia, and blurred vision. The frequency of seizures may increase, especially with overdose.
  • Other adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, serious hematological toxicity (aplastic anemia, agranulocytosis), and hypersensitivity reactions (dangerous skin reactions, eosinophilia, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly).
  • A late complication of therapy with carbamazepine is retention of water, with decreased osmolality and concentration of Na+ in plasma, especially in elderly patients with cardiac disease.
     
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 442.

questions.text: Which receptors are affected by tricyclic antidepressants, causing side effects like dry mouth and urinary retention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Muscarinic receptors

  • Tricyclic antidepressants produce side effects like dry mouth, urinary retention due to action on Muscarinic receptors.
  • Muscarinic receptors are the most widespread receptors of the parasympathetic nervous system bringing about associated changes in the body.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 485.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not include the usage of cholinomimetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Partial heart block

  • Cholinomimetic is not used in partial heart block because they cause Bradycardia and Heart block in severe patients.
  • At the A-V node and His-Purkinje fibres refractory period (RP) is increased and conduction is slowed, P-R interval increases and partial to complete A-V block may be produced.
  • The force of atrial contraction is markedly reduced and RP of atrial fibres is abbreviated.

* Uses of Cholinomimetic-

  • Diseases of eye: Glaucoma and accommodative esotropia
  • Gastrointestinal and urinary tract: Post-operative atony, neurogenic bladder
  • Neuromuscular junction: Myasthenia gravis, Curare induced neuromuscular paralysis
  • Heart: Certain atrial arrhythmias
  • Atropine overdoses
  • Alzheimer's disease

questions.text: What is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis ?
questions.solution:
1. In India, unlike the Western/developed world - the most common cause of neonatal sepsis are gram-negative bacilli-like Kleibsella/Acinetobacter/E.Coli etc. 
2. In India - most common cause of neonatal sepsis is Acinetobacter as per AIIMS NICU Protocols. Other Indian textbooks give Kleibsella as the most common cause.
3. In western world - most common cause is gram positive organisms - GBS (Group B streptococcus)
 
  • Since the question was asked in AIIMS/INICET - best answer is option 3 (Acenitobacter)
  • If the question was asked in NEET - Kleibsella is a better answer. 
  • If the question had asked - most common cause in the world or developed nations - then the answer is Group B Streptococcus. 

Answer has been confirmed by Professors of NICU/Pediatrics at AIIMS, Delhi. Answer might be given wrong in other Qbanks which do not have inside AIIMS information. Please mark Acenitobacter if asked in INICET. 

#controversial

Reference - AIIMS NICU Protocols 3rd edition, Chapter - Neonatal Sepsis, pg 254

questions.text: Area under Normal curve with \(\pm\)1 SD:
questions.solution:
Area under the Normal curve with +/- 1SD is 0.68.

In a normal distribution, about 68% of the data falls within ±1 standard deviation (SD) from the mean. This means:

  • Approximately 34% of the data lies between the mean and +1 SD.
  • Approximately 34% lies between the mean and -1 SD.

So, if you consider the area under the curve from -1 SD to +1 SD, it accounts for about 68% of the total area under the normal distribution curve.
 

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 11.

questions.text: Hemoglobin's mean value in a sample of 2000 people is 13.5 gm, which follows a normal distribution curve. What proportion of people have hemoglobin levels higher than 13.5 gm?
questions.solution:
In a population with a normal distribution, the mean, median, and mode are all the same.

As a result, the median here is also 13.5, dividing the population into two equal halves.
As a result, 50% will be on either side of 13.5.
Hence, the percentage of people with hemoglobin levels higher than 13.5 gm is 50.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 7.

questions.text: What is the statistical "Q" test used for?
questions.solution:
Q test is used for identification and rejection of outliers.

  • An outlier in statistics is an observation point that is separated from other observations. 
  • An outlier can be caused by measurement variability or by experimental error. 
  • Outliers can occur by chance in any distribution, but they are frequently indicative of either measurement error or a heavy-tailed distribution in the population.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 62.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about folic acid?
questions.solution:
• Fortification of wheat products (flour) is done with folic acid in the USA but not in India.
  • In 1996, the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) published regulations requiring the addition of folic acid to enriched breads, cereals ,flours, corn meals, pastas, rice, and other grain products.

Other options
  • Folic acid is present in most green leafy (The word folate itself is derived from 'folium' meaning 'leafy' since it was present in leafy vegetables)
  • Neural tube defects are reduced if folic acid is taken peri-conception. Folate should be started atleast 1 month prior to conception. The dose is 0.4mg. 10X dose is required if the prior child had Neural tube defect. 

  • Methyl folate trap occurs when methionine synthase (MS) is defective or there is Vitamin B12 deficiency. This enzyme converts 5-methyl-THF (methyl folate) into tetrahydrofolate (THF), allowing folate to enter the active cycle. Without B12 or functional methionine synthase, folate remains "trapped" as 5-methyl-THF, leading to functional folate deficiency.

questions.text: A diabetic patient, age 55, comes with brief vision impairment that lasts for two to three days until it is abruptly erased. Which test from the list below would be most effective in determining his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The above scenario signifies Amaurosis fugax i.e transient vision loss can be sign of Hyperhomocysteinemia.
 
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia refers to increased total plasma concentration of homocysteine with or without an increase in free homocysteine(disulfide form).
  • Homocysteine can act as an atherogenic and thrombophilic agent, and increased total plasma homocysteine has been associated with an increased risk for coronary, cerebrovascular, and peripheral arterial disease as well as for deep-vein thrombosis.
 
  • Classic homocystinuria, the most common (frequency 1:450,000), results from reduced activity of cystathionine β-synthase, the pyridoxal phosphate–dependent enzyme that condenses homocysteine with serine to form cystathionine.
  • Most patients present between 3 and 5 years of age with dislocated optic lenses and intellectual disability (in about half of cases). Some patients develop a marfanoid habitus and radiologic evidence of osteoporosis.
 
  • Life-threatening vascular complications (affecting coronary, renal, and cerebral arteries) can occur during the first decade of life and are the major cause of morbidity and mortality.
  • Classic homocystinuria can be diagnosed with analysis of plasma amino acids, showing elevated methionine and presence of free homocystine. Total plasma homocysteine is also extremely elevated (usually >100 μM).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3271, 3272.

questions.text: A patient who is a woman of childbearing age is taking valproate for JME. Which medication should be substituted for valproate and is acceptable for usage in monotherapy?
questions.solution:
• Levetiracetam
  • If valproate is taken during pregnancy, up to 4 in 10 babies are at risk of developmental disorders, and approximately 1 in 10 are at risk of birth defects.
  • Birth defects seen when mothers take valproate during pregnancy include:
  1. Spina bifida (where the bones of the spine do not develop properly)
  2. Facial and skull malformations (including cleft lip and palate, where the upper lip or facial bones are split).
  3. Malformations of the limbs, heart, kidney, urinary tract and sexual organs.

Levetiracetam is safer in pregnancy.


Reference-Williams Obstetrics 26th edition Page no 150

questions.text: A patient receiving amphotericin B develops 2.3 mEq/l of hypokalemia. How much K + supplementation is required?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 120-160 mEq over 24 hours
 
  • Here we need to correct potassium from 2.3mEq/L to 3mEq/L, therefore the difference is of 0.7mEq/L For every 1mEq/L increase in K+, KCl required is 200meq So the amount of KCl will be 0.7 x 200 = 140 mEq
  • Thus, the correct answer is 120-160 mEq over 24 hrs.

questions.text: A patient with aortic valve disease who also had right hemiparesis was admitted. What steps will you take to stop further strokes?
questions.solution:
• Aspirin is the only antiplatelet agent that has been shown to be effective in the acute treatment of ischemic stroke; however, there are several antiplatelet agents that have been shown to be effective in the secondary prevention of stroke.
 
  • Two large trials, the International Stroke Trial (IST) and the Chinese Acute Stroke Trial (CAST), found that the use of aspirin within 48 h of stroke onset reduced both stroke recurrence risk and mortality.

  • Numerous clinical trials have failed to demonstrate any benefit of routine anticoagulation in the primary treatment of atherothrombotic cerebral ischemia and have also shown an increase in the risk of brain and systemic hemorrhage. Therefore, the routine use of heparin or other anticoagulants for patients with atherothrombotic stroke is not warranted.

choices.text: Translocation between long arm of chromosome 9 and short arm of chromosome 22
Protein tyrosine kinase inhibitors are used in treatment

questions.text: Which statement regarding CML in children is correct?
questions.solution:
Option (2) is the correct statement among the given options.

Protein tyrosine kinase inhibitors (eg Imatinib/Dasatinib) are used in the treatment of CML.

Imatinib therapy regulates blood counts and significantly reduces the risk of progression to the accelerated phase and blast crisis, which pose the greatest risk to the patient. 

However, it is not a cure for the disease. 

Option (1) is incorrect.
CML occurs due to translocation t(9;22)(q34;q11.2) i.e. translocation between the long arm of chromosome 9 and the long arm of chromosome 22.

Option (3) is incorrect.
CML commonly presents in the chronic phase. Blast crisis at presentation is in only 1-2% of the cases. 

Option (4) is incorrect. 
ALL(70-80%) is the most common leukemia in children followed by AML(10-15). CML accounts for only about 5-7% of cases of leukemia in children. 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 818-827.

questions.text: After taking NSAIDS for a headache, a woman experienced dyspnea, pruritus, and urticaria one hour later. Examining the chest revealed rales with a blood pressure of 80/50 mm Hg. Except for _________, all of the following can be utilised for initial management.
questions.solution:
Colloid infusion has no/limited role in the management of Anaphylactic shock. Colloids are used in case of resuscitation of burns after first day. 
 
  • NSAID-induced hypersensitivity reactions can cause anaphylaxis, which presents with various symptoms such as difficulty breathing, skin manifestations, and hypotension. .
  • The initial management of anaphylaxis includes: Crystalloids infusion: to maintain blood volume and counteract hypotension. Early respiratory support and oxygenation: This is crucial to ensure adequate oxygen supply and relieve respiratory distress.
  • Adrenaline: Adrenaline (epinephrine) is the first-line treatment for anaphylaxis. It acts rapidly to reverse bronchoconstriction, increase blood pressure, and relieve symptoms.
  • Dose of adrenaline- 0.5mg IM 1:1000 dilution.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 516.

questions.text: In contrast-induced nephropathy, which of the following is a sign of renal impairment?
questions.solution:
Contrast nephropathy leads to a rise in serum creatinine within 24-48 hours, peak within 3-5 days, and resolution within 5-7 days.

Iodinated contrast agents, which are commonly used in cardiovascular and CT imaging, are a leading cause of AKI (Acute Kidney Injury). 

The risk of AKI, also known as "contrast nephropathy," is negligible in people with normal renal function, but it rises dramatically in people with chronic kidney disease, particularly diabetic nephropathy.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2300.

questions.text: Progressive jaundice was detected in a patient who was 50 years old. LFT revealed SGOT-50, SGPT-65, alkaline phosphatase-550 IU, direct and total serum bilirubin levels of 4.8% and 6.7% respectively. On clinical examination GB was non palpable. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis is Jaundice due to choledocholithiasis.
 
  • High Conjugated (Direct) bilirubin and increased alkaline phosphatase levels point towards post hepatic obstruction as seen in case of choledocholithiasis.
 
  • Serum bilirubin levels > 20 mg/dL should suggest the possibility of neoplastic obstruction, which is not seen in this case.
 
  • Moreover, According to Courvoisier's law, GB is palpable in Malignant Obstructive jaundice (Periampullary CA) whereas it is non palpable in Choledocholithiasis, due to repeated inflammation and fibrosis.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2553, 2554, 2557

choices.text: Negative nasogastric aspirate does not exclude variceal bleed
Nasogastric tube insertion can provoke variceal bleeding

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with alcoholic liver disease and a history of hematemesis presented to emergency. Which of the following statements about his management is false?
questions.solution:
NG tube insertion DO NOT provoke variceal bleed. Rather, it should be done to prevent aspiration in patients with acute variceal bleed. NG tube aspirate do not necessarily contain variceal bleed.
 
  • Treatment for esophageal varices as a complication of portal hypertension is divided into two main categories: (1) primary prophylaxis and (2) prevention of rebleeding once there has been an initial variceal hemorrhage.
 
  • Upper GI endoscopies are recommended at diagnosis of compensated cirrhosis and then every 2 years if the liver disease is active or every 3 years if inactive (alcohol cessation, viral hepatitis eradication). Endoscopy is also recommended at the time of hepatic decompensation.
 
  • The use of vasoconstricting agents, usually somatostatin or octreotide, has been shown to improve initial bleeding control and reduce transfusion requirements and all-cause mortality.
 
  • Balloon tamponade (Sengstaken-Blakemore tube or Minnesota tube) can be used in patients who need stabilization prior to endoscopic therapy or as a bridge to transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) after endoscopic failure


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2630.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with right hemiparesis and 2.5 hours of speech loss presented to emergency. BP is 180/100. What is the best course of action for managing this patient moving forward?
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of this patient is go for NCCT Brain.

  • Following the clinical diagnosis of stroke, a sequential process of evaluation and treatment should ensue. The first objective is to prevent or reverse brain injury.
  • Attend to the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) and, if hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia is detected, treat it.
  • Perform an emergency noncontrast head CT scan to distinguish between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke.



Management of Acute Stroke: 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3336, 3337.

questions.text: A 32-year-old Bengali woman presented with a 48-hour fever, a history of meaningless chatter, and two occurrences of tonic-clonic seizures that occurred back-to-back on the way to the hospital. She also had bizarre behaviour and memory disturbances. Before, she had been fine. Which medication from the list below can be administered while the other investigations are ongoing?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. IV acyclovir

The above clinical scenario with meaningless chatter, GTCS, abnormal behaviour and memory disturbances point the diagnosis towards HSV (viral) encephalitis.
 
  • The patient with encephalitis commonly has an altered level of consciousness (confusion, behavioral abnormalities), or a depressed level of consciousness ranging from mild lethargy to coma, and evidence of either focal or diffuse neurologic signs and symptoms.
  • Patients with encephalitis may have hallucinations, agitation, personality change, behavioral disorders, and, at times, a frankly psychotic state.
 
  • HSV encephalitis should be considered when clinical features suggest involvement of the inferomedial frontotemporal regions of the brain, including prominent olfactory or gustatory hallucinations, anosmia, unusual or bizarre behavior or personality alterations, or memory disturbance.
  • HSV encephalitis should always be suspected in patients with signs and symptoms consistent with acute encephalitis with focal findings on clinical examination, neuroimaging studies, or EEG.
 
  • Diagnosis: The diagnostic procedure of choice in these patients is CSF PCR analysis for HSV. A positive CSF PCR establishes the diagnosis.
 
  • Treatment: Acyclovir is of benefit in the treatment of HSV and should be started empirically in patients with suspected viral encephalitis, especially if focal features are present, while awaiting viral diagnostic studies.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1094, 1097.

questions.text: A 13 years old male child presented with abnormal body movements with MRI showing Abnormal T2 hyperintensity in the putamen. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Most likely diagnosis is Wilson's disease.

  • Wilson disease has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance and is characterized by tremors, rigidity, dementia, and pseudobulbar features. 
  • A Kayser-Fleischer ring may be discovered during a slit-lamp examination of the eyes. 
  • MRI in Wilson disease is characterized by high-intensity lesions in the basal ganglia, thalami, and midbrain on T2-weighted images.
  • The typical 'face-of-the-giant-panda' sign is caused by the normal low intensity of red nuclei and SN surrounded by abnormal high-signal intensity in the tegmentum of the mid brain. 
  • The best diagnostic clue is symmetrical T2 hyperintensity or mixed intensity in the putamen (with hyperintense putaminal rim) and globus pallidus, as well as the caudate nuclei and thalami.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2103-2105

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does glucocorticoid use decrease mortality?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Severe typhoid
 
  • In critically ill patients with enteric fever, combining dexamethasone with chloramphenicol resulted in a significantly lower mortality rate than chloramphenicol alone.
 
  • In cerebral malaria, corticosteroids can be used to decrease swelling but can reduce the host immunity response towards the infection as well.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1295.

choices.text: Sequential nerve demyelination followed by inflammatory myopathy during course of disease
Cranial nerves are involved more commonly than peripheral nerve
Diaphragmatic atony due to prolonged intubation may cause it

questions.text: What is true regarding the critical illness myoneuropathy?
questions.solution:
Diaphragmatic atony due to prolonged intubation may cause critical illness myoneuropathy.
 
  • Critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP) or critical illness myopathy (CIM) are the most common causes of weakness in critically ill patients in the ICU due to prolonged neuromuscular blockade. 
  • Both CIM and CIP develop as a complication of sepsis and multiple organ failure. They usually present as an inability to wean a patient from a ventilator.
 
  • Serum creatine kinase (CK) levels are usually normal; an elevated serum CK level indicates CIM rather than CIP.
  • In CIP, nerve conduction studies show that motor and sensory studies are absent or have significantly reduced amplitudes, whereas sensory studies are relatively preserved in CIM.
 
  • Improvement takes weeks in mild cases and months in severe cases. Over 50% of patients have reported complete recovery.
  • In more severe cases, however, recovery may be incomplete or may not occur at all.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3490.

questions.text: A patient fell unconscious two hours ago after experiencing a sudden, acute headache which he describes as the worst headache of life. He later became conscious but has neck rigidity and photophobia. What should be done after that?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis in this case is subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
 
  • In SAH, sudden loss of consciousness may be preceded by a brief moment of excruciating headache, but most patients first complain of headache upon regaining consciousness.
 
  • The patient often calls the headache “the worst headache of my life”; however, the most important characteristic is sudden onset.
 
  • NCCT head should be done in this case to confirm the diagnosis. On CT scans, subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) appears as a high-attenuating, amorphous substance that fills the normally dark, CSF-filled subarachnoid spaces around the brain. The normally black subarachnoid cisterns and sulci may appear white in acute hemorrhage.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354, 3355.

choices.text: Aspiration of 20-30 mL of contents with pH <2.5 is required
Fungal infection is the most common cause of pneumonia
Posterior segment of the right upper lobe is most commonly affected in the recumbent position
Aspiration is responsible for 5-15% of community acquired pneumonia

questions.text: About aspiration pneumonia, all of the following are true, barring:
questions.solution:
Aspiration pneumonia is an infectious pulmonary condition triggered by entering bacteria-rich oropharyngeal fluids into the lower respiratory tract. The aspirated fluid may contain oropharyngeal secretions, particulate matter, or gastric content.

Most common causative organisms of Aspiration Pneumonia are Oral anaerobes and gram negative enteric bacteria.
 
  • Option 1: Aspiration pneumonia is more likely to occur when pH of the aspirated fluid is less than 2.5 and the volume of aspirate is greater than 0.3 mL/kg of body weight (20-25 mL in adults).
 
  • Option 3: In supine positions, the posterior segments of the right upper lobe and the right apical segment of the lower lobe are the areas most likely affected. In the standing and sitting positions, the basal segments of the lower lobes, particularly of the right lower lobe, are usually affected.
 
  • Option 4: The incidence of aspiration pneumonia among patients with CAP ranges between 5% and 15% in the US, United Kingdom, and Korea.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1010, 1011.
Jordi Almirall et al., Aspiration pneumonia: A renewed perspective and practical approach, Respiratory Medicine, Volume 185, 2021. doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rmed.2021.106485. URL: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0954611121001918

questions.text: What is the most typical Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma subtype in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diffuse large B cell lymphoma

The most common subtype of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in India is diffuse large B cell lymphoma.
* [Extra Edge]: NHL types
B-Cell
1. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma: MC subtype (34%)
2. Follicular Centre-cell lymphomas: 12.6%
3. B-cell small lymphocytic lymphoma: 5.7%
4. Mantle-cell lymphoma: 3.4%
5. Marginal zone B-cell lymphomas (including MALT lymphomas): 8.2%
T-Cell
1. T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma: 6%
2. Anaplastic large-cell lymphomas of T/null-cell type
3. Other nodal peripheral T-cell lymphomas: 2.9%

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 600.

choices.text: Massive hemoptysis is bleeding >400 ml in 24 hours
CT chest is the next step in management
In an unstable patient, rigid bronchoscopy is done to identify the lesion

questions.text: What statement concerning hemoptysis is false?
questions.solution:
CT chest is the first investigation done that is a false statement for massive hemoptysis.
 
  • "Massive hemoptysis may be characterized as greater than 400 ml blood loss from the lungs in 24 hours (OR) >150 ml at a time.”
  • In 90% of cases, the bronchial circulation is the cause of massive hemoptysis.
  • The following step in the examination of hemoptysis should be a conventional chest radiograph for the majority of individuals.
  • If the cause of bleeding cannot be determined on plain film, a CT of the chest should be acquired. When these examinations are unrevealing, bronchoscopy should be taken into consideration. An 8.5-mm or bigger rigid bronchoscope is required.
  • As most large-volume hemoptysis results from an airway lesion, the location of the bleeding can be determined by either a chest x-ray or bronchoscopy.
  • Next step in management should be to secure the airway followed by identification of bleeding site. 

Approach to the management of Hemoptysis: 





 Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 270, 271.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an acquired cause of pure red cell aplasia?
Which of the following is not an admission criterion for upper GI bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Hematocrit > 40%
 
  • Hematocrit > 40% is not a criteria for admission in upper GI bleed as this is non specific and can be managed conservatively.
  • The indications for hospital admission and resuscitation in upper GI bleed are: Shock index >1.5 Frank blood in nasogastric aspirate BP <100 mm Hg.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1217.

choices.text: Detected by serum ferritin levels even in earlier states
Mostly presents without any symptoms with abnormal laboratory findings
Latent anemia is most prevalent in India

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
All of the following are true about iron deficiency anemia except that they mostly present without any symptoms with abnormal laboratory findings.

In iron deficiency, hemosiderin and ferritin decrease; supply of iron to the apotransferrin decreases resulting in decrease in transferrin saturation <16%.

In the First stage of iron deficiency reduction in storage iron is seen as fall in serum ferritin 

 

IDA is preceded by a stage of latent iron deficiency and its most prevalent in india.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 747-754.

questions.text: Which drug from the list below can be administered to people with primary pulmonary hypertension?
questions.solution:
Bosentan can be given in patients of primary pulmonary hypertension.

  • Bosentan is a FDA approved non-specific antagonist of endothelin receptors (ERA) of both ET-A & ET-B. 
 
  • ERAs prevent ET-1 from attaching to either endothelin receptor A (ET-A) or receptor B(ET-B). Vasoconstriction is mediated by ET-A receptors on the smooth muscle cells of the pulmonary artery. ET-B receptors are found on endothelial cells in the normal pulmonary vasculature, and they were found to mediate vasodilation by the synthesis of prostacyclin and nitric oxide as well as the clearance of ET-I.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2129.

questions.text: An obese 50-year-old woman presents with point hemorrhages in her scalp, bleeding in her joints, and erythematous lesions on her skin. The knee joint's X-ray suggested hemarthrosis. Which mechanism being defective leads to this ?
questions.solution:
A 50 years old female who is obese, probably because of junk food diet presented with point hemorrhages in the scalp, bleeding in joints and erythematous lesions in the skin. X-ray of knee joint was suggestive of hemarthrosis. Problem lies with Hydroxylation of proline and lysine. This patient is a case of Vitamin C deficiency leading to scurvy.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 43.

choices.text: Hypoglycemia, blood sugar level less than 40 mg

questions.text: Which of the following statements about severe malaria is not true?
questions.solution:
Hematocrit more than 15 is the incorrect statement.

All of the following are true about severe malaria except Hematocrit more than 15 as Hematocrit <15 is suggestive of severe malaria.

Malaria with the severe form of Falciparum shows:

  • <15% hematocrit or <50 g/L hemoglobin level and having a parasitemia level of more than 100,000/microL.
  • More than 3 mg/dL (>265 micromol/L) of serum creatinine 
  • plasma glucose level of <40 mg/dL (<2.2 mmol/L).
  • Unarousable coma
  • Acidosis pH < 7.25
  • SBP < 80 mm Hg 
  • Convulsions
  • Jaundice 
  • Pulmonary edema



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1724.

questions.text: An elderly patient with hypertension who developed a sudden onset headache, nausea, and neck stiffness but no localised neurological deficit. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly, hypertensive patient presented with sudden onset headache, vomiting, neck rigidity without focal neurological deficit, diagnosis in this case is subarachnoid hemorrhage.

NCCT is done to confirm diagnosis.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
 
  • MC cause: Trauma >Spontaneous rupture of Berry aneurysm
  • Clinical Features: Sudden transient loss of consciousness, Complaint of Severe headache in 45% of cases and is more commonly on regaining consciousness. Neck stiffness and vomiting without Focal neurological deficit and Sudden headache in the absence of focal neurological deficit is the hallmark sign.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354.

questions.text: What is the mortality rate linked with emergency abdominal aortic surgery?
questions.solution:
Mortality associated with emergency abdominal aortic surgery is >50%.

The operational mortality rate is about 1-2% with adequate preoperative cardiac examination and after care. 

The mortality rate of an emergency procedure following an acute rupture is 45–50%. In Abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture Less than half of victims make it to the hospital. Death is practically certain if no surgery is done. More than 50% of patients survive if operation is done.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1017.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lactating mother appeared with a bothersome breast lump. What is the best way to begin an investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) USG

Since the lady is a lactating mother with a painful breast lump, Most appropriate initial investigations would be USG to r/o Breast milk retention. The age is not a criteria in this question.

Indications of breast USG:
 
  • Symptomatic breast lump in women <35 years.
  • Breast lump during lactation and pregnancy.
  • Assessment of mammographic abnormality .
  • Assessment of MRI .
  • Breast mass along with a negative mammogram.
  • Breast inflammation.
  • Breast lumps in males along with MRI Needle biopsy for localisation.
  • Follow-up of breast carcinoma.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 915.

questions.text: A lactating woman complains of painful breasts. What should be the first investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) USG

A lactating female presents with painful breast. First investigation to be done in this case is USG.

Indications of breast USG:

  • Symptomatic breast lump in women <35 years.
  • Breast lump during lactation and pregnancy.
  • Assessment of mammographic abnormality .
  • Assessment of MRI .
  • Breast mass along with a negative mammogram .
  • Breast inflammation.
  • Breast lumps in males along with MRI
  • Needle biopsy for localisation.
  • Follow-up of breast carcinoma.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 915.

questions.text: The doctor was searching for curling ulcers in a burn patient. Which area should be examined?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. 1st part of duodenum
 
  • In a burn patient, the doctor was looking for curling ulcer and 1st part of duodenum must be examined for the same as the closest to stomach is 1st part of duodenum. 
  • Curling ulcers are Characterized by multiple, superficial erosions after a burn injury that begin in the proximal acid releasing portion of stomach and invade distally and is rare in antrum and duodenum.
  • They are acute ulcers which develop after major burns, presenting as pain in epigastric region, vomiting or hematemesis. Treatment is conservative-IV ranitidine. IV pantoprazole 80 mg in 100 ml DNS-slow, later 40 mg IV maintenance.
  • Curling's ulcer occurs when burn injury is more than 35%. It is observed in the body and fundus not in antrum and duodenum.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 813.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is used to confirm anorchia?
questions.solution:
• Diagnostic laparoscopy is a definitive investigation for anorchia.
  • Inguinoscrotal USG and MRI are not helpful in the diagnosis of nonpalpable testis.
  • Diagnostic laparoscopy followed by laparoscopic orchidopexy if the testis is in the abdomen is the preferred approach.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1870.

choices.text: Per-rectal examination to check ejaculatory duct obstruction

questions.text: "Female partner is normal in a couple undergoing infertility treatment for the last four years. On two repeated samples, the male partner has 0.8 mL semen volume per ejaculate, no fructose, and no sperms when examined under a microscope. What is the next level of investigation?"
questions.solution:
• In a couple for treatment of infertility from the last four years, the female partner is normal.
  • Male partner has 0.8ml semen volume per ejaculate on two repeated samples and absent fructose, with no sperms on examination under microscope.
  • The next line of management would be Transrectal ultrasound to detect duct obstruction.
  • Absence of fructose and the absence of sperm in the ejaculate point to vas deferens blockage with seminal vesicle agenesis or occlusion.
  • Surgical vasography has been substituted by TRUS in the diagnosis of obstructive lesions that result in infertility.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1455.

questions.text: A patient who suffered spinal, chest, and abdomen injuries in an automobile accident experienced hypotension and bradycardia. What is the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
A patient with spine, chest and abdominal injury in a road traffic accident developed hypotension and bradycardia. Most likely reason is neurogenic shock.
Neurogenic shock may be caused by the interruption of sympathetic vasomotor input following a high cervical spinal cord injury, unintentional cephalad migration of spinal anesthesia, or a catastrophic head injury.
Venodilation results in pooling in the venous system, which reduces venous return and cardiac output in addition to causing arteriolar dilatation and extremities are often warm. Hypovolemic and septic shock will cause tachycardia.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 402.

questions.text: What does FAST stand for?
questions.solution:
FAST stands for Focused assessment with sonography for trauma.

  • FAST is a quick diagnostic test used to evaluate patients who may have suffered thoracoabdominal injuries. 
  • FAST takes 2-4 minutes to complete. 
  • FAST progressively examines the pericardial sac, the right upper quadrant (RUQ), the left upper quadrant (LUQ), and the pelvis for the presence or absence of blood.
  • eFAST or extended FAST involves examination of left and right chest for pneumothorax. 
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 378.

choices.text: Insert wide bore needle in 2nd intercostal space

questions.text: Following a car accident, a patient developed tension pneumothorax. What is the first line of action?
questions.solution:
First line of management in tension pneumothorax: Insert wide bore needle in 2nd intercostal space in the Mid axillary line. 

With diminished breath sounds and shock, this instance is a classic illustration of a tension pneumothorax of the right hemithorax.
The fact that Patient  is shouting indicates that her airway is open. The urgent treatment for this patient is immediate decompression with a large bore needle in the midclavicular line in the second intercostal gap, followed by IV line insertion and fluid delivery.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 374.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and dysuria. Patient was admitted in an emergency room for 5 days. The PSA level was 7.4. Which of the following is the best next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
A 60 years old male presented with fever, chills and dysuria. Patient was hospitalized in an emergency for 5 days. PSA level was 7.4. This patient is most probably suffering from acute bacterial prostatitis and is treated by antibiotics.

Acute Bacterial Prostatitis :

  • Patients present with sudden onset high grade fever with chills and rigors, severe irritative symptoms and enlarged, tender and boggy prostate
  • Catheterisation and prostatic massage is contraindicated.
  • Treatment:-TMO-SMX and Ciprofloxacin.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 2067.

questions.text: The best way to treat a contaminated wound with necrotic material is to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Debridement

Best management of contaminated wound with necrotic material is debridement.

Exploration and debridement of wounds should be done to the limit of blood staining. With the obvious exception of nerves, arteries, and tendons, devitalized tissue must be removed till the bleeding occurs.

* [Extra Edge]:

Debridement plays a crucial part in the management of trauma. Wounds sustained in disasters are often heavily contaminated, containing foreign bodies and non-viable tissues. Debridement reduces the chances of anaerobic and necrotizing infections and can prevent systemic sepsis.
 
  1. After the administration of anasthesia, the injured area is copiously irrigated with normal saline. Lavage using a pressurised system is controversial, with concerns over tissue trauma and spread of debris. A waterjet based system that simultaneously clears the debris after debriding is very useful. The wound is palpated and all foreign matter removed. Dirt and debris enmeshed in soft tissues can only be removed by excision of those tissues. Open joints should be thoroughly irrigated and all foreign material removed.
  2. The next step is excision of all dead and devitalised tissue. At this stage the tourniquet is let down to check the vascularity of the tissues. Skin excision is kept to a minimum and only the margins of the wound need be trimmed back to healthy bleeding edges.


Fig: Gross contamination wounds in need of proper debridement

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 452.

questions.text: Which triage colour is assigned the highest priority?
questions.solution:
Red

Triage, which literally means "to sort," entails classifying victims according to the seriousness of their injuries, their chances of surviving, and the need for immediate medical attention. Priority is given to red and it denotes a critical patient.

TRIAGE scheme:

  • Red colour: First priority and signifies a critical patient.
  • Yellow colour :Urgent, second priority
  • Green colour: Minor injuries, ambulatory patient.
  • Black colour: Expectant or dead patients.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 449.

choices.text: Peak incidence in 3 years old children in India
Most common type in ammonium urate or calcium oxalate

questions.text: Which of the following statements about endemic bladder stones is incorrect?
questions.solution:
False regarding endemic bladder stones is that it always associated with recurrence. The prevalence of primary bladder calculi is higher in children who consume low-protein, low-phosphate diets.
  • After therapy, primary bladder calculi seldom reoccur. Stones are often solitary and don’t usually reappear after being removed.
  • The most frequent elements of primary bladder calculi are uric acid, calcium oxalate, ammonium acid urate, and calcium phosphate.
  • Children in endemic areas frequently eat a diet high in cereal that is low in animal protein and low in phosphate.
  • Low dietary phosphate intake causes both hyperammonuria and hypophosphaturia, which encourages the precipitation of calcium oxalate and ammonium acid urate.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1509.

questions.text: Withdrawal to pain stimulation falls under what category on the Glasgow coma scale?
questions.solution:
In the Glasgow coma scale, withdrawal to pain stimulus comes under M4.

* Glasgow Coma Scale score for head injury: 



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 363.

questions.text: What is the tumor marker for seminoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) PLAP

Tumor marker for seminoma is PLAP

Tumor marker for seminoma is PLAP (Placental alkaline phosphatase) but beta-HCG is also increased in 5-10% of pure seminoma, as they contain syncytiotrophoblast-like giant cells.

Other tumor markers for testicular tumors are-

  • alpha feto protein-YOLK sac and embryonal carcinoma.
  • LDH-marker for bulk disease
  • GGT (Gamma glutamyl transpeptidase)-seminoma testis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 970.

questions.text: A 60-year-old guy arrives at the emergency department in an unconscious state, gains consciousness, and then returns to unconsciousness. What is the name given to the moment he becomes conscious?
questions.solution:
A 60-years-old man presents to the emergency department with a history of RTA, in an unconscious state and gains consciousness in between but again becomes unconscious. The time when he becomes conscious is called Lucid interval.
This is a stage of sanity during which all signs and symptoms vanish totally. The person is capable of making sound judgements about his actions, and he can also assume legal responsibility for them. Epidural hematoma, sanity, and melancholia are all characterized by lucid intervals.

* Epidural Hematoma:
1. Epidural hematoma is present between the skull and dura mater.
2. Appearance- convex lens-shaped hemorrhage on CT.
3. Cause: blunt trauma, frequently to the temporal region (the skull is thin at pterion).
4. Middle Meningeal artery is involved.
5. 30-50% of cases have a lucid interval.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 397.

questions.text: A young healthy male patient appeared with stomach pain and a 6-month history of changed bowel habits. On CT, there was a dilated distal ileum, a thickened ileocecal junction, a thickened cecum, and sacculations on the antimesenteric boundary. The vascularity of the adjacent mesentery is likewise enlarged, and there is fat around the mesentery. Which of the following does not constitute a distinct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4. Ischemic bowel disease
 
  • Ischemic bowel disease can’t be the differential diagnosis as in Ischemic bowel disease or mesenteric ischemia, vascularity of adjoining mesentery is decreased.
  • History of abdominal pain and altered bowel habit with thickened cecum and ileocecal junction and increased vascularity of surrounding mesentery can be observed in Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease and tuberculosis.
  • Signs and symptoms of ischemic colitis reflect the extent of bowel ischemia. In mild cases, patients may have diarrhea (usually bloody) without abdominal pain.
  • With more severe ischemia, intense abdominal pain (often out of proportion to the clinical examination), tenderness, fever, and leukocytosis are present. In CT scan Thumb Print sign is seen. 
  • Peritonitis and/or systemic toxicity are signs of full thickness necrosis and perforation.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1309.

questions.text: Which of the following does not use neo-adjuvant chemotherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Breast cancer stage 1

There is no role of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in Stage 1 Breast CA.
Currently, neoadjuvant chemotherapy is offered to patients with locally advanced breast cancer and also those breast cancer patients who may benefit from size reduction before conservation therapy.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 940.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical features is present only in pregnancy with  heart disease  and not in normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Distended neck veins are seen in pregnancy with heart disease, but not seen in normal pregnancy.

Because of heart disease mainly right sided heart failure increased jugular venous pressure upto + 5cm is seen due to high cardiac output causing neck vein distension.

Supine hypotension is a condition that develops in late pregnancy when the gravid uterus compresses the I.V.C when the patient is supine.As a result, hypotension is generated. 

Exertional dyspnea :-Pregnancy causes a state of hyperventilation,which is most likely caused by progesterone's effects on the respiratory center and the center's increased sensitivity to carbon dioxide. The woman feels her breath getting shorter. 

Pedal edema also seen due to decreased colloidal osmotic tension due to hemodilution.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 60.

questions.text: All of the following complications is more common in ventouse-assisted delivery than forceps EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Fetal asphyxia is more common in forceps assisted delivery and NOT in ventouse assisted delivery.
Subgaleal hemorrhage, cephalhematoma and intracranial hemorrhage are more common in ventouse assisted delivery.

Complications of Forceps Operation:

Maternal:
  • vaginal laceration
  • sulcus tear
  • cervical tear
  • complete perineal tear
  • Nerve injury: Femoral (L2, 3, 4), lumbosacral trunk with mid forceps delivery
  • Post-partum hemorrhage
  • Anesthetic complications: Puerperal sepsis and maternal morbidity

Fetal:
  • Asphyxia
  • facial bruising

Complications of ventouse operation:

Maternal: injuries are not common

Fetal:

questions.text: Which week of pregnancy has the highest cardiac output?
questions.solution:
28 weeks
Physiological changes in the
cardiovascular system during pregnancy 
• During pregnancy, there is an increase in cardiac output by increasing heart stroke volume and heart rate 
• Increasing CVS begins with 10 weeks of pregnancy and reaches a maximum of 29-36 weeks of pregnancy 
• Increasing CVS occurs due to the increase in plasma volume to to 35-47% and the volume of circulating red blood cells at
11-30%, as a result, the hematocrit decreases to 33-38% 
• Pregnancy worsens CVD and can lead to emergency conditions that require urgent measures, not only from the obstetrician but also from the therapist cardiologist surgeon.
