questions.text: A 20-week-pregnant woman complains of vaginal bleeding. On speculum examination, the OS is open, but no products have emerged. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Inevitable abortion  

DEFINITION: It is the clinical type of abortion where the changes have progressed to a state from where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.
CLINICAL FEATURES: The patient, having the features of threatened miscarriage, develops the following manifestations: (1) Increased vaginal bleeding. (2) Aggravation of pain in the lower abdomen which may be colicky in nature. (3) Internal examination reveals dilated internal os of the cervix through which the products of conception are felt. On occasion, the features may develop quickly without prior clinical evidence of threatened miscarriage. In the second trimester, however, it may start with rupture of the membranes or intermittent lower abdominal pain (mini labor).
MANAGEMENT is aimed: (a) to accelerate the process of expulsion. (b) to maintain strict asepsis. General measures: Excessive bleeding should be promptly controlled by administering Methergine 0.2 mg if the cervix is dilated and the size of the uterus is less than 12 weeks. The blood loss is corrected by intravenous (IV) fluid therapy and blood transfusion.
Active Treatment
  • Before 12 weeks: (1) Dilatation and evacuation followed by curettage of the uterine cavity by blunt curette using analgesia or under general anesthesia. (2) Alternatively, suction evacuation followed by curettage is done.
  • After 12 weeks: (1) !e uterine contraction is accelerated by oxytocin drip (10 units in 500 mL of normal saline) 40–60 drops per minute. If the fetus is expelled and the placenta is retained, it is removed by ovum forceps, if lying separated. If the placenta is not separated, digital separation followed by its evacuation is to be done under general anesthesia.
Other options- 
  • Incomplete abortion- will have history of Product of conception coming out 
  • Complete abortion- initial bleeding and POC came out now bleeding stopped and OS is closed.
  • Missed abortion- history of brown discharge now OS closed. 



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 189.

questions.text: A 26-year-old healthy girl became pregnant for the first time, and LSCS was performed to treat foetal distress. During pregnancy, she had mild hypertension. She developed headaches and seizures two days after delivery, but no proteinuria was found. A CT scan reveals a 2×3 cm parasagittal hematoma. Diagnosis will be:
questions.solution:
• A 26 year old healthy female got pregnant for Ist time and LSCS was done for fetal distress. Mild hypertension was present during pregnancy. Two days after delivery she had a headache and seizures but proteinuria was not seen. CT scan shows 2× 3 cm parasagittal hematoma. Diagnosis is sagittal sinus thrombosis.
 
  • A side effect of oral contraceptive use, pregnancy and the postpartum period, inflammatory bowel disease, intracranial infections (meningitis), and dehydration is venous sinus thrombosis of the lateral and sagittal small cerebral veins (cortical vein thrombosis). 
 
  • Patients typically arrive with headaches along with a variety of neurological symptoms, particularly paresthesias and seizures. However, venous sinus blockage is easily visible utilizing MR-or CT-venography or traditional x-ray angiography. Often, CT imaging is normal unless an intracranial venous hemorrhage has occurred.




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 474.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 319.

questions.text: What is the radiation dose for early and locally advanced carcinoma of the cervix at point A during brachytherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. 70-75 Gray and 75-80 Gray
 
  • Point A was defined as a point 2 cm above the cervical os and 2 cm apart from os on the line perpendicular to uterine axis. It is a hypothetical point representing the crossover of the ureter and uterine artery, located in the paracervical triangle, and is considered as a critical point for radiation tolerance.
  • On the other hand, point B, which was designated as 5 cm from the midline at the level of point A, represented the dose delivered to the pelvic lymph node.
  • It has been calculated that point A gets about 7000–8000 cGy and point B 2000 cGy. Taking into consideration that cancerolytic dose is approximately 7000–7500 cGy, the rest of the dose at point B is supplemented by external beam irradiation of 4000 cGy spreading over another three weeks.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 497.

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning the latent phase of labour is false?
questions.solution:
The latent phase of labor is the time between the beginning of labor symptoms and the onset of the active phase. Hence, Statement 2 is a wrong statement.

First Stage of labor It consists of two phases:
• Latent Phase- Cervical effacement and early dilatation occurs
• Active Phase- It begins when the cervix is 2-4 cm dilated in the presence of regular uterine contractions. More rapid cervical dilatation occurs
 
  • The onset of latent labor, as defined by Friedman (1972), is the point at which the mother perceives regular contractions. For most women, this phase ends once cervical dilation of 4 cm is achieved.
  • This threshold may be clinically useful, for it defines dilation limits beyond which active labor can be expected.
  • More recently, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine (2019c) has redefined active labor to begin at 6 cm.




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 424, 425.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female complains of primary amenorrhea with a high FSH level. Her height was measured at 58 inches. What would the ovary's histopathology findings be?
questions.solution:
• Primary amenorrhea with high FSH and short stature(58 inches height) is highly suggestive of Turner syndrome.
  • Turners syndrome is caused due to a missing or partially missing X chromosome (Karyotype - 45, XO)
  • One of its characteristic features is streak ovaries. Clinical Features of Turner's Syndrome include: Short stature Streak ovaries: They do not experience puberty or menstruation.
  • Lack of Secondary sexual characteristics: underdeveloped breasts, a narrow pelvis, and a lack of pubic hair. Cardiac and/or renal defects. Eg bicuspid aortic valve/horseshoe kidney,Webbed neck, Low-set ears, Broad chest with widely spaced nipples, Cubitus valgus, The forearms may curve outward at the elbows, Low posterior hairline, Multi-pigmented naevi.

questions.text: Which form of aberration in sexual development has the best prognosis?
questions.solution:
• Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is a type of abnormality in sexual development, which has the best prognosis.
  • It is possible to treat congenital adrenal hyperplasia by giving the body enough glucocorticoids to stop the overproduction of androgens.
  • Surgery can be used to treat the genital abnormality (enlarged clitoris, fusion of labia minora).
  • The prognosis has improved as a result of efforts to treat CAH in pregnancy and newborn screening techniques to detect it. CAH patients can become pregnant and give birth to healthy children.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 522-524

questions.text:
An eight-year-old boy experiences increased physical weakness. His calves are thick and exhibit muscle tightening after examination. His serum creatine kinase levels rise with ageing.
Which of the following diagnoses is more likely?
questions.solution:
• Most likely diagnosis is Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy due to Dystrophin deficiency.
  • DMD typically starts in early childhood (around 2-5 years of age).
    • It begins with weakness in the proximal muscles (those closer to the trunk), especially in the legs and pelvis, leading to difficulty with running, climbing stairs, and walking.
    • Over time, it affects other muscle groups, leading to generalized muscle wasting.

  • Gowers' Sign: This is a classic sign where the child uses their hands and arms to "climb up" their own body to stand up from a sitting or lying position due to weakness in the hip and thigh muscles.

  • Calf Muscle Pseudohypertrophy: The calves often appear large and muscular due to the replacement of muscle tissue with fat and fibrous tissue, a phenomenon called pseudohypertrophy.

  • Elevated Creatine Kinase (CK) Levels: Blood levels of CK, an enzyme released by damaged muscles, are significantly elevated in DMD patients, sometimes up to 10-100 times the normal range, even before symptoms appear.

  • Cardiac and Respiratory Complications: As DMD progresses, it affects the heart muscles, leading to cardiomyopathy and heart failure. Respiratory muscles also become weak, leading to breathing difficulties and an increased risk of respiratory infections, typically in the teenage years or early adulthood.



    Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3281-3284

questions.text: GTCS develops in a premature newborn aged 2 days. What investigation should be conducted to diagnose the pathology?
questions.solution:
• A 2 days old premature neonate develops GTCS.The investigations done to diagnose the pathology is Transcranial ultrasound.
  • The major imaging technique for premature neonates is cranial ultrasonography, which is also ideal for studying newborns in general.
  • It is carried out at the patient's bedside and offers accurate measurement of the size of the ventricles and other fluid-containing lesions, as well as accurate observation of hemorrhagic and ischemic lesions and their development.
  • Transcranial USG could be done in neonates due to the presence of fontanelles. 
 

Reference: AIIMS NICU Protocols 2 nd Edition page no 78

choices.text: A baby born at 28 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A Pediatrician in a district hospital with a specialized neonatal care unit will consult with an ophthalmologist for which of the following newborns?
questions.solution:
• A pediatrician in a district hospital's specialized neonatal care unit will call an ophthalmologist for consultation for a baby born at 28 weeks of gestation in order to screen for retinopathy of prematurity.
  • Other newborns don't require screening for ROP/Ophthalmologist consult.
  • Retinopathy of prematurity occurs when premature newborns (32 weeks or less 1.5 kg) are exposed to high oxygen concentrations during their first 10 days of life, bilateral proliferative retinopathy can develop.
  • Screening/Prophylaxis Between 32 and 36 weeks post-conception, all infants with birth weights or gestational ages 1500 gm or 32 weeks should undergo an indirect ophthalmoscopy screening.
  • Infants who are premature shouldn't be kept in incubators with oxygen concentrations higher than 30%. Babies born prematurely should be screened at 1, 3, and 6 months old, as well as every 4 months up to 4 years old.
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3377-3379

questions.text: A 6-year-old Afro-American boy reported with abdominal pain, chronic hemolysis, and aberrant RBC shape on a peripheral smear. This condition is most likely caused by a:
questions.solution:
• An Afro-American kid of 6 years of age presented with abdominal pain ,chronic hemolysis and abnormal RBC shape on peripheral smear - Most likely this is Sickle Cell disease.
  • In Sickle cell disease, there is Point-mutation that affects the nucleotide triplet CTC, which codes for glutamic acid (or GAG in mRNA), is altered to CAC, which codes for valine (or GUG in mRNA).
  • Sickle cell anemia is caused by a single amino acid change that modifies the physicochemical characteristics of hemoglobin leading to formation of HbS.
  • The majority of people with sickle cell disease, a prevalent genetic hemoglobinopathy, are of African heritage.
  • Heterozygosity is as high as 30% in Africa HbS formed polymerises when a person experiences hypoxia or acidosis and causes hemolysis, micro vascular occlusions and tissue damage.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 342,343

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to treat cyanotic episodes in a TOF patient?
questions.solution:
Calcium chloride is not given in the treatment of cyanotic spells in a patient of TOF.

Cyanotic spells are seen in tetralogy of fallot.

Tetralogy of Fallot:

  1. Pulmonary stenosis
  2. Ventricular septal defect
  3. Right ventricular hypertrophy
  4. overriding of aorta.
 

Management of anoxic or cyanotic spells:

In case of cyanotic spells there is reduced pulmonary blood flow. Thus the target is to increase the peripheral resistance so that the systemic flow is reduced and pulmonary flow increases. 

  • Knee chest position, humidified oxygen & Morphine  0.1 to 0.2 mg/kg SC.
  • If acidosis detected :  sodium bicarbonate 1-3 ml/kg IV
  • Propranolol 0.1 mg/kg/IV-0.5-1 mg/kg/6hourly
  • Vasopressors like Phenylephrine & Methoxamine IM or IV drip.
  • Manage the anaemia and consider surgery.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 419

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is not associated with uniparental disomy?
questions.solution:
• Uniparental disomy is not related to bloom syndrome. Bloom syndrome is due to DNA repair defect. 
  • When both of a pair of chromosomes in a person with a normal number of chromosomes have been inherited from just one parent, the condition is known as uniparental disomy.
  • Uniparental disomy is linked to Angelman syndrome, Prader-Willi syndrome, and Russell-Silver syndrome.
  • Uniparental disomy and a genomic imprinting (chromosome 15) abnormality are the causes of the Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 634
 Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 676

questions.text: On the first day, a baby starts frothing at the mouth with choking on feeding. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Esophageal atresia is the most probable diagnosis of a newborn with frothing from the mouth and choking present on day one of life.
  • Esophageal atresia is a pathology in which a baby's esophagus is not fully developed.
  • Esophageal atresia: When a baby spits up excessively and coughs or chokes during the first oral feeding, the diagnosis of esophageal atresia is considered.

questions.text: A six-month-old baby has been complaining of a cough and a cold for the past three days. The rate of respiration is 48/min. The patient is having low grade fever, with no chest indrawing but wheezing. Which of the following is not correct?
questions.solution:
A 6 month old baby has been coughing and cold for the last three days. Respiratory rate is 48/min.
Patient is having low grade fever, there are no chest retractions but wheezing is present. This child is not suffering from pneumonia, as respiratory rate is <50/ minute and there is no chest indrawing/no high grade fever or any feature suggestive of severe pneumonia. 

In children under 2 months old, children between 2 months and 1 year old, and children between 1 and 5 years old, a high respiratory rate/fast breathing pneumonia is defined as >60 breaths per minute, >50 breaths per minute, or >40 breaths per minute respectively. 

As per IMNCI - for no pneumonia - only symptomatic management is required (salbutamol if wheezing/PCM for fever) - there is no need for antibiotics.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 377-380

questions.text: Which of the following is required to establish the diagnosis of H-type trachea-esophageal fistula?

  • To establish the diagnosis of H-type trachea-esophageal fistula in difficult cases, Tracheo-esophagoscopy is required. TEF is an abnormal communication (fistula) between the esophagus and trachea.
  • It can be of different types based on the defect. Congenital isolated TEF (H-type) is a rare disorder and this leads to difficulties in its diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 3 days old baby is admitted with intraventricular hemorrhage. Baby develops abdominal distention. The X-ray abdomen showed pneumatosis portalis (portal vein gas). What would be the stage of NEC?
questions.solution:
The presence of pneumatosis portalis signifies that the stage of Necrotizing Enterocolitis is stage 2B. The 'Modified Bell's staging criteria’ is used to determine the severity, radiography, and management of Necrotizing Enterocolitis.
According to this staging, 'pneumatosis portalis’ (presence of gas in the portal vein) indicates stage 2B; Pneumatosis intestinalis is 2A.

questions.text: Children with germline retinoblastoma are more likely to acquire other primary cancers later in life. Which of the following cancers can develop in such patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Osteosarcoma of lower limbs

  • Children with germline retinoblastoma are more likely to develop other primary malignancies in their later lifetime.
  • These non-metastatic malignancies which develop in disease free patients are known as second site tumors. The most common among them is osteosarcoma.
  • Other Tumors associated with retinoblastoma include osteosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, Ewing’s sarcoma, epithelial malignant tumors, lymphoma, leukemia, melanoma, brain tumors and pinealoblastomas.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 291.

questions.text: A four-year-old girl complained of an abdominal lump. In which of the following diagnosis for the above lump is a bone scan required?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Neuroblastoma
 
  • In Neuroblastoma, a bone scan is required since metastases is evident in 60-70% of patients at the time of diagnosis and the most common site of metastasis in older children is bones.
  • Most (40%) present under the age of 1 year, 35% between ages 1 and 2 years and 25% older than 2 years.
  • Many present with signs and symptoms related to tumour growth or they may be incidental ultrasonographic fndings. Presenting symptoms include malaise and/or pain or obstruction of veins or lymphatics or hydronephrosis.
  • Acute or subacute paraplegia can develop from spinal cord or nerve root involvement. Many children (70%) have metastases at the time of presentation. Rarely the tumor secretes VIP, which results in diarrhoea, dehydration and hypokalemia.
  • NBs may secrete catecholamines, leading to elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrines. Serum lactate dehydrogenase is a useful tumour marker.
  • An unequivocal diagnosis is from histology of either the tumour or bone marrow aspirate. Imaging is undertaken to stage the disease using CT or MRI and MIBG. In children with regional or metastatic disease, biopsy is necessary for diagnosis and prognostication.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 902.

questions.text: While playing hockey, a 24-year-old college student hurt his right knee. After 3 months, this patient presents with knee joint instability in full extension without instability at 90 degrees of flexion. What is the most usually damaged structure?
questions.solution:
• Posterolateral bundle of anterior cruciate ligament is the most commonly damaged structure in above-mentioned situation.
  • The Anterior cruciate ligament is composed of two principal parts:- A Small anteromedial bundle and a large bulky posterolateral portion.
  • The Anteromedial bundle is tight in flexion and the Posterolateral portion is tight in extension.

Reference- Online resource  https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499848/

questions.text: Gallows traction is used on a 2-year-old toddler. The child has a fracture in the:

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause infant clubfoot?
questions.solution:
• Polio infection occurs postnatally and causes paralysis.
  • It is not responsible for causing clubfoot in newborns, clubfoot is most commonly idiopathic or due to congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV).

Other causes of club foot are:

• Neurological disorders and neural tube defects (myelomeningocele, spinal dysraphism)

• Paralytic disorders such as spina bifida, myelodysplasia and Freidreich's ataxia

• Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita

• Larsen syndrome

• Freeman-Sheldon (Mobius) syndrome

• Diastrophic dwarfism

• Sacral agenesis, tibial deficiency, constriction rings and amniotic bands

• Fetal alcohol syndrome

• Down's syndrome

• Larsen syndrome

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man came in with significant pain and edema in his left great toe. On X-ray, a punched out lytic lesion with sclerotic boundaries and overhanging bone edges is evident on the phalanx.
The diagnosis seems to be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical history is suggestive of Gout.

  • Gout is a metabolic disease that most often affects middle- aged to elder men and postmenopausal women.
  • Acute attack typically involves the first metatarso-phalangeal joint (Great toe).

X-ray of feet in gout shows:

  • soft tissue swelling
  • cystic changes
  • well-defined 'punched-out' type lytic lesions with sclerotic margins
  • overhanging bony edges (Martel's sign, G sign or rat-bite erosion).

 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2863, 2864.

questions.text: In which of the following are both the bone and disc gaps destroyed?

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
• A T-score of - 2.5 or less is seen in osteoporosis.
  • T-scores are statistical scores used in tests to compare individual results to those of the young population which is matched for race and sex. They help to determine if there is any significant difference in the results of these two populations.
  • A T-score of less than -1.0 but greater than -2.5 is considered osteopenia, while a T-score of -2.5 or lower is considered osteoporosis
Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 308,309

questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment.
 
  • Degenerative myopia, characterized by severe nearsightedness and progressive elongation of the eyeball, increases the risk of retinal detachment.
  • The stretching and thinning of the retina in degenerative myopia can lead to retinal tears or breaks, which may progress to retinal detachment if left untreated.

Other options:
  • Degenerative myopia is seen in more than 6 dioptres of myopia.
  • It is more common in females as compared to males. 
  • The condition has a racial predilection; it is more common in Jews and Japanese people, and most cases are of genetic origin.
  • Retinal tears are more common in degenerative myopia and can occur at any stage.

Reference: Parson’s diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 64.

questions.text: What is the most prevalent cause of bilateral proptosis in kids?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate answer would be Neuroblastoma as it is the most common cause of bilateral proptosis in children (more common than RB/RMS)

Metastatic neuroblastoma(<5 years) and/or acute myeloid leukemia (chloroma)(>5 years) should be considered in any child presenting with bilateral proptosis.

The Most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children is orbital cellulitis.


Reference- Parson's diseases of the eye 23rd edition Page no 345

questions.text: Where does optical atrophy not occur?
questions.solution:
Optic atrophy is not seen in polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy.

While Retinitis pigmentosa, Methanol poisoning and Central retinal arterial occlusion (CRAO) can lead to optic atrophy.

Causes of Optic atrophy:



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 870.

questions.text: What causes a band-shaped keratopathy to develop?
questions.solution:
• Band shaped keratopathy is a degenerative change caused due to the deposition of calcium salts in Bowman's membrane, superficial part of corneal stroma and the deeper layers of epithelium.
  • It can be idiopathic, age related or associated with chronic eye diseases such as Chronic uveitis, JRA (Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis), Sarcoidosis, Chronic glaucoma, Chronic keratitis; systemic conditions like Sarcoidosis, Hyper-parathyroidism, Vitamin D toxicity, Extensive metastatic neoplasm to bone, Chronic renal failure (secondary hyper-parathyroidism); or local corneal damage.


 

Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 189.

questions.text: Which cells are most frequently impacted by glaucomatous optic atrophy?
questions.solution:
Ganglion cells are the most commonly affected cells in glaucomatous optic atrophy.

Glaucoma is second leading cause of blindness and is characterized by optic disc changes and visual field defects. Due to increased intraocular pressure, there is loss of retinal ganglion cells (RGC) and their axons over a period of many years.



 

Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 261.

questions.text: Regarding indirect ophthalmoscope, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Indirect Ophthalmoscopy Direct Ophthalmoscopy "bird's eye" view - wide field, 20-30 degress, depending on the lens - able to scan the entire retina rapidly Very small field of view - extremely laborious to study the entire retina Binocular view - stereopsis - see in "3 D" Uniocular view - no steropsis Image upside down and backwards Image erect Better performed while the patient is lying Better performed in sitting position Better view in hazy media Very poor in hazy media Periphery of the retina can be examined even to the ora serrata Periphery of retina beyond equator is difficult to see Examination of the retina performed with patient at "arms length" Examination of the retina performed with the examiners face immediately against the patient's face.




Reference- Parson's diseases of the eye 23rd edition Page no 113

questions.text: During a prone dark room test, a 36-year-old woman has eye pain. Which medication from the list below has to be avoided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Atropine
 
  • In the given case where a 36-year-old female on prone dark room test develops pain in the eyes. This is due to pupillary dilatation in the dark causing obliteration of the narrow angle in the anterior chamber. The most probable diagnosis is angle closure glaucoma.
  • Atropinic drugs are absolutely contraindicated in individuals with a narrow iridocorneal angle—may precipitate acute congestive glaucoma since it is a anticholinergic drug.

Option 1 acetazolamide reduces aqueous formation by limiting generation of bicarbonate ion in the ciliary epithelium. It is used to supplement ocular hypotensive drugs for short-term indications like angle closure, before and after ocular surgery/laser therapy.

Option 2 and 4 pilocarpine and timolol have cholinergic/ parasympathomimetic action they penetrate cornea and promptly causes miosis, ciliary muscle contraction and fall in intraocular tension. Timolol is better than pilocarpine in cases of chronic dosing as the action is smooth and well sustained with lesser side effects like no induced myopia, no headache / brow pain and no fluctuation of i.o.p etc. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 132.

questions.text: Concentration of tropicamide:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 1:0.01

Tropicamide acts on M3 receptors and causes passive Mydriasis.
Mechanism of action – Cycloplegic and mydriatic
Use – Ocular fundal examination, Refractive error testing in adults
Concentration – 1% Drugs acting on the pupil

*[Extra Edge]:

Tropicamide has the quickest (20–40 min) and briefest (3–6 hours) action but is a relatively unreliable cycloplegic. However, it is satisfactory for refraction testing in adults and as a short acting mydriatic for fundoscopy. Phenylephrine is often combined with tropicamide for faster and stronger mydriatic action.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 130.

choices.text: Equal concentration of soluble and insoluble protein

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the protein content in senile cataracts is correct?
questions.solution:
More insoluble proteins and less soluble proteins are seen in lenses with senile cataract.

  • In young individuals, most of the lens proteins are soluble but with age, some crystallines become insoluble and this is an important pathology in senile cataractogenesis.
  • Below the age of 50 years, approximately 4% of lens proteins are insoluble, but by the age of 80 years, this increases to 40%–50%.
  • Up to 80% of the nuclear proteins of an aged lens may be insoluble, and most of the nuclear α-crystallin is insoluble by the age of 45 years. This contributes to the loss of lens transparency and the development of senile cataract.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 326e9.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 194.

questions.text: After vitamin A deficiency, what changes are visible in the conjunctiva?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Hyperkeratosis of squamous epithelium.
 
  • Changes seen in the conjunctiva in vitamin A deficiency is hyperkeratosis of the squamous epithelium.
  • This occurs due to the metaplasia of the non-keratinized epithelium to keratinized epithelium. 
WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency:





Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 487, 488.
Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 730, 731.

questions.text: Which drug from the list below should not be administered to a patient with narrow-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Homatropine
 
  • Anticholinergic agents like- Atropine, Cyclopentolate, Homatropine can precipitate angle closure glaucoma and is thus contraindicated.
  • Mydriasis is a precipitating factor for angle closure glaucoma as it reduces the angle and Homatropine is a mydriatic agent. 
  • Pilocarpine, Timolol and Acetazolamide are used for the treatment of angle closure glaucoma.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1064.

choices.text: Probe can be passed underneath the pterygium at the limbs
Elastotic degeneration with distortion of Descemet's membrane

questions.text: • Which of the following statements regarding pterygium is correct?
questions.solution:
Pterygium is a wing-shaped, triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue that can encroach onto the cornea.
The Bare sclera technique refers to the surgical removal of the pterygium without any additional tissue graft or covering. This technique has been associated with a relatively high recurrence rate ranging from 30% to 80%, making it a less preferred option for pterygium surgery.

Other options:
  • Probe test helps to differentiate pterygium from pseudopterygium. Probe test is negative in pterygium i.e Probe cannot be passed underneath the pterygium. (Option 1)
  • Pterygium is primarily associated with long-term exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight, not infrared radiation. (Option 2) 
  • This statement describes pinguecula, not pterygium. Pinguecula is a condition characterized by yellowish conjunctival deposits that do not extend onto the cornea. It is associated with elastotic degeneration and can cause distortion of Descemet's membrane. (Option 4)


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 206, 207.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 89-91.

questions.text: Which one of the following contains long-spaced collagen?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Cornea
 
  • Long-spaced collagen is seen in the corneal stroma in old age.
  • This is a special arrangement of collagen seen in the old age which is not seen in younger individuals and it correlates with the age related changes seen in cornea.
  • Long spaced collagen is not seen in diaphragm, tympanic membrane or basement membrane.




Reference: Hirano K, Nakamura M, Kobayashi M, Kobayashi K, Hoshino T, Awaya S. Long-spacing collagen in the human corneal stroma. Jpn J Ophthalmol. 1993;37(2):148-55. PMID: 8230839.
Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 156.

questions.text: Topical steroid use is not advised in?
questions.solution:
Topical steroids are not recommended in post-surgery for antrochoanal polyps.

The cause of antrochoanal polyps is infection, not allergies and thus Topical steroids are rarely advised. They are given post-surgery in ethmoidal polyp, allergic fungal sinusitis and chronic rhinosinusitis.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 195

choices.text: Extracapsular approach is best for cold approach
Adenoids should also be removed if significantly involved
Cricothyroid region is high and anterior in children than adults

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding tonsillectomy in children?
questions.solution:
Intracapsular approach is preferred over extracapsular approach in tonsillectomy for cold approach. In children aged 5 to 19 years, it results in less postoperative pain than extracapsular tonsillectomy. Obstructive Sleep apnea is the most common indication for tonsillectomy and adenoids should be removed along with tonsillectomy if they are significantly involved. Larynx is placed anteriorly and higher in children as compared to adults which is why cricothyroid is also higher and more anterior.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 489

questions.text: What is implanted during the cochlear implant surgery?
questions.solution:
The internal components of a cochlear implant are the receiver/stimulator (implanted under the skin) and the electrode array (implanted in the Scala tympani of the cochlea).

Microphone, Speech-processor, and Transmitter are components of the cochlear implant that remain outside the body.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 139

questions.text: After eating peanuts, the patient had laryngeal edema, stridor, hoarseness, and tongue swelling. The most likely conclusion is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in the given history of peanut intake, swelling of tongue, stridor is angioneurotic edema or angioedema.

Allergic angioedema is the most common type and is commonly seen in people having food allergies. In severe cases swelling of the throat can also be seen which0, makes it difficult for the patient to breathe. A sudden drop in blood pressure may also be present. It is treated as a medical emergency.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 329

questions.text: A 36-year-old overweight prominent smoker was snoring and had hypertension. Five apnea/hyperpnea events occurred during each hour of the sleep test. He was prescribed anti-hypertensives and told to give up smoking. What will be in the next line of action?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of an obese, hypertensive patient with 5 AHI episodes/hour and snoring episodes is suggestive of Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA).

Management of OSA: 
 
  • A comprehensive approach to the management of OSA is needed to reduce risk factors and comorbidities. The clinician should seek to identify and address lifestyle and behavioral factors as well as comorbidities that may be exacerbating OSA. As appropriate, treatment should aim to reduce weight; optimize sleep duration (7–9 h); regulate sleep schedules (with similar bedtimes and wake times across the week).
 
  • However, CPAP is the treatment of choice. CPAP is the standard medical therapy with the highest level of evidence for efficacy. Delivered through a nasal or nasal-oral mask, CPAP works as a mechanical splint to hold the airway open, thus maintaining airway patency during sleep.
 
  • Upper airway surgery for OSA is less efficacious than CPAP and is mostly reserved for the treatment of patients who snore, have mild OSA, or cannot tolerate CPAP. Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (removal of the uvula and the margin of the soft palate) is the most commonly performed surgery for OSA


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2208, 2209.

questions.text: Tympanometry was ordered for a 35-year-old pregnant woman who complained of hearing loss that has gotten worse during pregnancy. Which type of graph will be seen?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has otosclerosis, which is more common in females and worsens during pregnancy. On tympanometry As type of curve would be observed which shows decreased compliance of tympanic membrane and normal middle ear pressure. The decreased compliance is due to fixation of footplate of stapes seen in otosclerosis. Ad curce sugests ossicular discontinuity.B curve is a flat curve and suggests fluid in ear. C curve represents retracted TM.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 27

questions.text: Which of the following is not advised for a patient who has been prescribed general anesthesia and has epilepsy?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Ketamine
 
  • Ketamine should be avoided in patients who have a history of seizures since it raises ICP and produces delirium and hallucinations.
  • Ketamine is a sympathomimetic drugs as it inhibits the metabolism of catecholamines and can, therefore trigger seizures.
  • Ketamine increases cerebral metabolism, CBF, and ICP. Because of its excitatory CNS effects, which can be detected by generalized EEG development of theta wave activity and by petit mal seizure-like activity in the hippocampus
  • Hallucination is the most common side effect of ketamine and is seen in 30-40% of the people.
  • Auditory hallucinations are more common than visual hallucinations
Other options: 
  • Option 1: Propofol may suppress seizure activity via GABA agonism, inhibition of NMDA receptors, and modulation of slow calcium ion channels. Propofol has neuroprotective action.
  • Option 2 & 4: Thiopentone and Midazolam has anti-epileptic property as they act via the GABA-A receptors to release GABA. Thiopentone has anticonvulsant action due to its phenyl group. Midazolam is a benzodiazepine used in treatment of seizures.
Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 641, 642, 656, 663.

questions.text: What is the name of the drug that causes malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Suxamethonium

  • Suxamethonium is the most common drug causing malignant hyperthermia.
  • Other drugs causing malignant hyperthermia are halothane (most common inhalational cause), iso/des/sevo/methoxy – fluranes, lignocaine, TCA, MAO inhibitors and phenothiazines.
  • Thiopentone and pancuronium are protective for malignant hyperthermia, as they raise the triggering threshold.
  • Anesthetics which are safe in malignant hyperthermia include: N2O, non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, opiates, tranquilizers and barbiturates.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 406.

questions.text: What is the name of the drug that causes malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 2) Succinylcholine

  • Succinylcholine is the most common drug causing malignant hyperthermia. 
  • Other drugs causing malignant hyperthermia are halothane (most common inhalational cause), iso/des/sevo/methoxy – fluranes, lignocaine, TCA, MAO inhibitors and phenothiazines.
  • Thiopentone and pancuronium are protective for malignant hyperthermia, as they raise the triggering threshold.
  • Anesthetics which are safe in malignant hyperthermia include: N2O, non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, opiates, tranquilizers and barbiturates.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 381.

questions.text: Which muscle is affected by tubocurarine first?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Head and neck

  • Tubocurare affects head and neck muscles first. The first muscles that Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants and Non-Depolarizing
  • Muscle Relaxants block are central muscles, which include the muscles of the face, jaw, pharynx, and larynx and muscles of respiration including diaphragm.
  • Sequence of blockade: Face, jaw muscles, pharynx, larynx, intercostals, diaphragm, abdominal muscles, trunk muscles and then peripheral muscles (limb muscles).
  • Recovery proceeds in the same order as blockade. In central muscles, blockage develops faster, lasts for a shorter period of time, and recovers more swiftly. Muscles in the face and limbs recover first and last, respectively.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 122.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in CPCR, according to "AHA 2023 Guidelines"?
questions.solution:
• According to the "AHA 2023 Guidelines", atropine is not recommended for use in cardiac arrest as a routine medication during cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).
  • Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that can increase heart rate and is used to treat certain types of bradyarrhythmias protocol
  • Recent studies have shown that it does not improve outcomes in cardiac arrest and may even be harmful in some cases. Therefore, the AHA no longer recommends the routine use of atropine during CPR.
  • Instead, the focus is on high-quality chest compressions, early defibrillation, and appropriate medications such as adrenaline and amiodarone.




Reference: Adult algorithm cardiac arrest algorithm, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 
Turkish out-of-hospital cardiac arrest study: TROHCA, Turkish Journal of Emergency Medicine, 24, 3, (133-144), (2024).https://doi.org/10.4103/tjem.tjem_73_24

questions.text: The patient started wheezing intra-op during a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Which of the following is applied during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Deepen the plane of anesthesia
 
  • If the patient develops wheezing while performing laparoscopic cholecystectomy, he should be treated by deepening of the plane of anesthesia.
  • The most frequent reason for asthma attacks during surgery is insufficient depth of anesthesia.
  • First, deepen anesthetic level and raise FiO2. Keep in mind that the patient is undergoing surgery and is sedated.
  • A deeper level of anesthesia can relax the airway muscles and reduce the likelihood of airway reflexes, such as bronchospasm or wheezing. Additionally, deepening anesthesia can reduce intra-abdominal pressure and minimize other mechanical triggers of wheezing.
  • Consequently, the use of medical intervention such as the administration of beta-agonists/Ketamine cane be given

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 415.

questions.text: At what level is the sensory block for lower segment caesarian sections given?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. T4
 
  • Because afferent nerves supplying abdominal and pelvic organs accompany sympathetic fibers that travel in the sympathetic trunk (T5 to L1), a sensory block that extends from the sacral dermatomes to T4 is needed for cesarean delivery.
  • A level of sensory blockade extending to the T4 dermatome is desired for cesarean delivery.
  • A dose of 10 to 12 mg of bupivacaine in a hyperbaric solution is administered. The addition of 20 to 25 μg of fentanyl improves the quality and prolongs the duration of the spinal block, reduces shivering, and minimizes referred pain.
  • In addition, 0.1 to 0.2 mg of intrathecal morphine can be added for pain control postoperatively.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 472.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contraindicate a neuraxial block?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Patient on antihypertensive medication
 
  • Patient on antihypertensive medication is not a contraindication for neuraxial block.
  • Absolute contraindications include: Patient’s refusal, Patient’s inability to maintain stillness during the needle puncture (can be seen in case of dementia, psychosis).
  • Raised intracranial tension, Severe Hypovolemia, Severe stenotic valvular heart disease, Marked skin sepsis and marked spinal deformity, Marked coagulopathy, blood dyscrasias or full anticoagulant therapy.
  • Relative contraindications include: Pre-existing neurological deficit (demyelinating lesions) due to medicolegal problems, All severe and marked diseases present in lesser degree (spinal deformity, sepsis), Pre-eclamptic toxemia, Mildly impaired coagulation, Patients with platelet <80,000/ml(bleeding could lead to hematoma formation). 


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1420, 1421.

choices.text: Replacement of stylet prior to removal of needle

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effective strategy to decrease the risk of post-puncture dural headache?
questions.solution:
Supplementation, of fluid does not prevent post-dura/ puncture headache (PDPH). 

Techniques for prevention of Post-dural Puncture Headache are: 

Use of atraumatic pencil-point spinal needle, Direction of bevel insertion parallel to the longitudinal dural fibers for cutting needles, smaller needle size, replacement of stylet before withdrawing the spinal needle, Ultrasound guided neuraxial blocks, lesser number of lumbar puncture attempts.

POST DURAL PUNCTURE HEADACHE:

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle 

Management: 

  1. Supine position
  2. IV fluids
  3. Caffeine and analgesia
  4. Epidural blood patch 



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no 1712.
Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology, 5th edition, Page no 969.

questions.text: Induction of anesthesia with an inhaled agent occurs more faster with?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Combined with nitrous oxide
 
  • lnduction of inhalational agent is faster, if it is combined with nitrous oxide.
  • The second gas effect usually refers to nitrous oxide combined with an inhalation agent.
  • Since nitrous oxide is not soluble in blood, it is rapidly absorbed from the alveoli, which causes the concentration of the other inhalational anesthetic to suddenly rise, hastening the induction process.
  • An inhalation anesthetic's rate of induction and recovery is primarily determined by the blood gas partition coefficient; lower the blood gas partition coefficient, the faster the induction and recovery.
  • Higher the functional residual capacity, greater is the time required for the anesthetic mixture to replace the normal lung gases.
  • Right-to-Left intracardiac shunt prolongs induction because the systemic arterial blood anesthetic partial pressure rises at a slower rate.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 518-520.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is receiving alendronate medication for osteoporosis for the past seven years. She now claims to be experiencing right thigh pain. What is the next investigation being conducted?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: X-ray.

The given clinical scenario of a 70 year old osteoporotic female on medications, presenting with right thigh pain points towards diagnosis of femoral fracture. Therefore, the next step is to perform a plain radiograph to order to look for fracture site. 

Crescent sign seen on xray of neck of femur fracture. 



The pain in right thigh in a 70 years old female, who is on treatment with alendronate for 7years for osteoporosis might be caused due to fragility fracture because of prolonged use of bisphosphonates. 

X-ray would be the best investigation to see the fractures. 


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1090.
Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 138, 139.

questions.text: Who is the most likely to develop spinal injury with symptoms but no radiological evidence?
questions.solution:
• Symptomatic spinal injury without any radiological evidence is most commonly seen in children.
  • Following trauma, computed tomography (CT) and plain radiographs which are the commonly used radiological investigations do not rule out spinal cord injury.
  • This is especially important for children because there is a condition known as SCIWORA (spinal cord injury without radiological abnormality), and the changes may only be detected on MRI.
  • Early (within 6 hours) administration of high dose methylprednisolone improves the outcome.

Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 328

questions.text: Radiologically, which of the following does not indicate increased pulmonary blood flow?
questions.solution:
• Septal lines/Kerley lines-Seen due to thickening of interlobular septa in the pulmonary interstitium. Occur due to either lymphatic engorgement or edema of the connective tissues of the interlobular septa.
  • Seen when pulmonary capillary wedge pressure reaches 20-25 mmHg. Kerley A lines 2-6 cm long oblique lines that are <1 mm thick and course towards the hila. Represent thickening of interlobular septa which contains lymphatic connections between the perivenous and bronchoarterial lymphatics deep within the lung parenchyma.
  • On chest radiographs, they cross normal vascular markings and extend radially from the hilum to the upper lobes. Best modality for the demonstration of Kerley A lines-HRCT chest. Kerley B lines Thin lines, 1-2 cm in length seen in the periphery of the lung. Perpendicular to the pleural surface and extend out to it. Represent thickened subpleural interlobular septa and are usually seen at the lung bases.
  • Kerley C lines Short lines which neither reach the pleura (i.e. not B or D lines) nor do they course radially away from the hila (i.e. not A lines).
  • Kerley D lines Same as Kerley B lines, except that they are seen on lateral chest radiographs in retrosternal air gap. Increased pulmonary blood flow is indicated by all of the following except Kerley B lines.
  • Kerley B lines are horizontal, subpleural lines 1-3 mm in thickness, 1 cm in length and the most common location is in the lower zones, peripherally at costophrenic angles and parallel to each other but perpendicular to the pleural surface. They are seen in pulmonary venous hypertension which is only an indirect marker of increased pulmonary blood flow.
 


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 397-399.

questions.text: A patient with limb and chest RTA injuries has a low SpO2 level. A right upper chest M-mode ultrasound reveals the stratospheric sign. What was the medical opinion?
questions.solution:
A patient of Road Traffic Accident with injury over chest and limbs who has low SpO2 and M-mode ultrasound of right upper chest shows stratosphere sign. The most probable diagnosis in this case is Pneumothorax. 

An ultrasound finding called the "stratosphere sign" can indicate the presence of pneumothorax and is typically found during an eFAST examination.
The sign is an image finding made with a 3.5-7.5 MHz ultrasonic probe in the machine's M-Mode in the 4th and 5th intercostal spaces in the anterior clavicular line.
This feature, which is fairly accurate for the diagnosis of pneumothorax, is evident in the M-mode tracing as the pleura and lung being indistinguishable as linear hyperechogenic lines.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1631.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who was referred by the endocrinology department reported limping and hip pain. Which of the subsequent tests is useless?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: USG Pelvis.

The given clinical scenario of an adolescent 12 year old boy being referred by endocrinology department with c/o limping and hip pain points towards diagnosis of Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis. 

  • Type I Salter-Harris growth plate injury due to repeated trauma with underlying mechanical and hormonal predisposing factors.
  • During growth, widening of the physeal growth plate is seen which is particularly pronounced during growth spurt.
  • Axis of the physis also alters during growth and moves from being horizontal to being oblique. 
  • With increasing obliquity, shear forces across the growth plate increase which causes increased risk of fracture and resultant slippage.
  • Ultrasound is of poor diagnostic yield in SCFE and should not be used as a replacement for a pelvic radiograph. 
  • Findings are nonspecific such as hip joint effusion and/or malalignment of the femoral epiphysis and metaphysis. 


A 12 years old boy referred from the endocrinology department who complains of pain in hip joint with limping. This boy is most probably suffering from slipped capital femoral epiphysis. USG pelvis is not very useful for the diagnosis of slipped capital femoral cheaply.

CT is useful in demonstrating closure of the proximal femoral epiphysis,

Assessment of severity of residual deformity, and penetration of hip joint by fixation device. MRI can diagnose SCFE well.


Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 542, 543.

questions.text:
A patient with a history of alcoholism is brought to the emergency room by his wife. Due to religious obligations, the person has abstained from alcohol for the past two days.
The participant reported feeling queasy, nauseated, and dizzy. He began having seizures on the second day, which later turned into widespread tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS).
Which of the following would be the most effective medication to treat the patient's seizure?
questions.solution:
The seizures in this patient and above clinical features are suggestive of Delirium tremens, due to acute alcohol withdrawal.

  • Delirium tremens (DTs), where the withdrawal includes delirium (mental confusion, agitation, and fluctuating levels of consciousness) associated with a tremor, seizure and autonomic overactivity (e.g., marked increases in pulse, blood pressure, and respirations).
  • Diazepam would can be used to manage the seizure of the patient. 
 
  • Although most depressants are effective, benzodiazepines have the most supportive data for use in this situation, combining a high level of safety and low cost.
  • To treat mild-moderate, uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal, either long acting benzodiazepines like chlordiazepoxide or diazepam or short-acting ones like lorazepam can be taken.
  • Chlordiazepoxide is favoured over diazepam for this purpose.
  • Liver disease is associated frequently with alcohol use. 
Benzodiazepines safe in Liver disease-
LOve The liver
L- Lorazepam
O- Oxazepam
T- Temazepam




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3561.

questions.text: Vegetables are not being eaten by a child. Each time he finishes a serving of vegetables, his mother starts giving him a chocolate. The condition is described as:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Operant conditioning 
 
  • The technique used in this case by the mother is known as operant conditioning.
  • In operant conditioning, a reward or punishment system is used to inculcate some specific behavior. In the given scenario, chocolates are used as rewards.
  • Operant conditioning is a type of learning in which behavior is strengthened or weakened by the consequences that follow it. In this scenario, the child's behavior of finishing a serving of vegetables is being reinforced by the reward of receiving a chocolate. This reward serves as a positive reinforcement, making it more likely that the child will repeat the behavior of finishing their vegetables in the future.
  • Classical conditioning is a learning process that occurs when two stimuli are repeatedly paired: a response which is at first elicited by the second stimulus is eventually elicited by the first stimulus alone.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 101-103.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient complains of persistent abdominal pain, but biochemical tests and an abdominal ultrasound show nothing abnormal. She suddenly complains of losing eyesight in both eyes after waking up from sleep. Ophthalmologist conducts examination and finds nothing. This condition is most likely because of:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Malingering
The given condition is most probably a case of Malingering.
 
  • Since the examination findings do not correlate with the history given by the patient for both, symptoms of the eye and GIT symptoms.
  • Malingering can be defined as the act of fabricating or exaggerating the symptoms of mental or physical disorders for a variety of 'secondary gain' motives, which may include financial compensation (often tied to fraud); avoiding school, work or military service; obtaining drugs; getting lighter criminal sentences; or simply to attract attention or sympathy.
  • Psychological evaluation, the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2) in particular, can be used to diagnose malingering.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 476, 494.

questions.text: What is a cognitive remediation used for?
questions.solution:
Cognitive remediation is used for cognitive restructuring. 

  • Cognitive remediation therapy (CRT), also known as cognitive enhancement therapy (CET), is a type of cognitive rehabilitation therapy developed at Kings College in London with the goal of enhancing neurocognitive skills like executive functioning, planning, flexibility, attention, and working memory.
 
  • These skills all contribute to social functioning.




Reference: Fan, Qing et al. “The Application of Cognitive Remediation Therapy in The Treatment of Mental Disorders.” Shanghai archives of psychiatry vol. 29,6 (2017): 373-375. doi:10.11919/j.issn.1002-0829.217079. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5925589/
